f.d: [24. rab mtshe ma'i gnas rnam par 'phrul ba'i le'u]
BOOK NINETEEN. Ascent to the Palace of the Suyama Heaven

de nas sangs rgyas kyi mthus shar phyogs kyi 'jig rten gyi khams thams cad dang / lho phyogs kyi 'jig rten gyi khams thams cad dang / gzhung de bzhin du steng gi phyogs kyi 'jig rten gyi khams kyi bar thams cad na gling bzhi pa 'di la sogs pa gling bzhi pa re re na de bzhin gshegs pa mang po bzhugs par snang ngo/ / byang chub sems dpa' de dag kyang de bzhin gshegs pa'i byin gyi rlabs kyis chos ston to/ / bdag kyang de bzhin gshegs pa'i byin gyi rlabs kyis chos ston to/ / bdag kyang de bzhin gshegs pa'i zhabs kyi drung na 'khod par shes so/ /

THEN, BY THE SPIRITUAL POWER of the Enlightened One, in all worlds of the ten directions, in the Jambu continent of each of the four quarters, and on the peak of their polar mountains, the Enlightened One was seen in the midst of an assembly, wherein the enlightening beings, due to the spiritual power of the Buddha, expounded the Teaching, each one having the sense of facing the Buddha at all times.

bcom ldan 'das kyis rdzu 'phrul mngon par 'du mdzad pa ma bshig ma btang bar byang chub kyi shing drung yang ma spangs par ri rab kyi rtse mo nas mtshe ma'i gnas kyi lha'i bu rab mtshe ma'i khang pa nor bu sna tshogs gang na ba der gshegs par snang ngo/ / ji ltar gling bzhi pa 'di na bcom ldan 'das rab mtshe ma'i gnas su gshegs par snang ba de bzhin du 'jig rten gyi khams thams cad na yang rab mtshe ma'i gnas su gshegs par snang ste/ byin gyi rlabs snga ma rnams kyang de bzhin ma 'khrugs par snang ngo/ / de nas lha'i rgyal po rab mtshe mas bcom ldan 'das rgyang ring po nas khang pa nor bu sna tshogs logs su mngon par gshegs pa mthong nas rings pa'i gzugs su khang pa nor bu sna tshogs kyi nang du de bzhin gshegs pa'i gdan rdzu 'phrul gyis bsgrubs pa'i seng+ge'i khri pad+mo'i snying po can/ lha rdzas kyi rin po che las byas pa/ bog re brgya stong phrag bcus kun nas brgyan pa/ gser gyi dra ba brgya stong phrag bcus kun nas mngon par bres pa/ me tog gi bla re brgya stong phrag bcus kun tu khyab par byas pa/ phreng ba'i bla re brgya stong phrag bcus kun tu brgyus pa; spos kyi bla re brgya stong phrag bcus spos thams cad kun tu 'thul bar bdug pa/ rin po che'i bla re brgya stong phrag bcus kun tu bres pa/ me tog gi gdugs brgya stong phrag bcu kun nas bzung ba/ phreng ba'i gdugs brgya stong phrag bcus kun nas bzung ba/ rin po che'i gdugs brgya stong phrag bcu kun nas bzung ba/ 'od zer brgya stong phrag bcus snang bar byas pa/ rab mtshe ma'i lha'i rgyal po brgya stong phrag bcus rab tu btud pa/ tshangs pa brgya stong phrag bcus mngon par phyag bya ba/ byang chub sems dpa' brgya stong phrag bcus mngon par bstod pa/ rol mo brdung ba brgya stong phrag bcus sgra phyung ba/ chos kyi glu'i dbyangs brgya stong phrag bcu'i glu'i dbyangs dang ldan pa/ me tog gi sprin gyi char brgya stong phrag bcu rab tu phab pa/ phreng ba'i sprin gyi char brgya stong phrag bcu rab tu phab pa/ rgyan gyi sprin gyi char brgya stong phrag bcu rab tu phab pa/ gos kyi sprin gyi char brgya stong phrag bcu rab tu phab pas kun nas yog pa/ nor bu rin po che'i sprin brgya stong phrag bcu'i char rab tu phab pas kun tu snang bar byas pa/ dge ba'i rtsa ba brgya stong phrag bcus kun nas byung ba/ sangs rgyas brgya stong phrag bcus byin gyis brlabs pa/ bsod nams brgya stong phrag bcus bsags shing bsgrubs pa/ lhag pa'i bsam pa brgya stong phrag bcus shin tu sbyangs pa/ smon lam brgya stong phrag bcus rnam par dag par byas pa/ spyod pa brgya stong phrag bcus kun nas bslab pa/ chos brgya stong phrag bcus rab tu brtan pa/ rnam par 'phrul ba brgya stong phrag bcu dang ldan pa/ yon tan brgya stong phrag bcus shin tu 'phags pa/ brjod pa brgya stong phrag bcu shin tu brjod pa bshams so/ / ji ltar gling bzhi pa 'dir rab mtshe ma'i gnas kyi lha'i rgyal por mtshe ma'i khang pa nor bu sna tshogs su de bzhin gshegs pa'i gdan gting ba de bzhin du 'jig rten gyi khams thams cad kyi gling bzhi pa dag gi rab mtshe ma'i gnas su yang khang ba nor bu sna tshogs su lha'i rgyal po rab mtshe ma rnams kyis de bzhin gshegs pa'i gdan rgyan 'di 'dra ba dang / bsham pa'i tshul 'di 'dra ba dag kyang bting bar gyur to/ /

At that time the World Honored One, without leaving the foot of the enlightenment trees and the peaks of the polar mountains, headed for the jewel-adorned hall of the palace of the Suyama heaven. The king of the Suyama heaven, seeing from afar the Buddha coming, produced by magical powers a jewel lotus bank lion throne in his palace, with a million tiers of decorations, wrapped in a million golden nets, covered with a million drapes of flowers, a million drapes of garlands, a million drapes of perfumes, and a million drapes of jewels, surrounded by a million canopies each of flowers, garlands, perfumes, and jewels; a million lights illumined it. A million celestial kings of the Suyama heaven bowed in respect, a million Brahma kings danced for joy, a million enlightening beings sang praises. A million heavenly symphonies each played a million tones of truth, continuing endlessly; a million clouds of various flowers, a million clouds of various garlands, a million clouds of various ornaments, and a million clouds of various robes, covered all around; a million clouds of various wish-fulfilling jewels shone with light. The throne was born from a million kinds of roots of goodness, protected by a million Buddhas, augmented by a million kinds of virtues, dignified and purified by a million kinds of faith and a million kinds of vows, produced by a million kinds of action, established by a million kinds of truths, conjured up by a million kinds of spiritual powers, always producing a million kinds of sounds revealing all truths.

de nas lha'i rgyal po rab mtshe mas bcom ldan 'das kyi gdan bting nas zhe sa dang / rim gror bcom ldan 'das gang na ba de logs su thal mo sbyar te phyag 'tshal nas bcom ldan 'das la 'di skad ces gsol to// bcom ldan 'das/ gshegs su gsol/ bde bar gshegs pa/ gshegs su gsol/ de bzhin gshegs pa dgra bcom pa yang dag par rdzogs pa'i sangs rgyas bde bar gshegs sam/ de nas bcom ldan 'das lha'i rgyal po rab mtshe mas spyan drangs pa bzhin du khang pa nor bu sna tshogs su gshegs so/ / ji ltar gling bzhi pa 'dir rab mtshe ma'i gnas su lha'i rgyal po rab mtshe ma'i khang pa nor bu sna tshogs su gshegs pa de bzhin du 'jig rten gyi khams thams cad du yang rab mtshe ma'i gnas kyi khang pa nor bu sna tshogs su gshegs par snang ngo/ / de nas lha'i rgyal po rab mtshe mas lha'i dbang po'i gnas thams cad du sgra bsgrags te/ lha'i rgyal po rab mtshe mas bcom ldan 'das la gsol ba btab bo/ /

Then that celestial king, having set out this throne, turned to the Buddha, the World Honored One, bowed and joined his palms with reverence and respect and said, “Welcome, O World Honored One; welcome, Felicitous One; welcome, Enlightened One; welcome, O Worthy; welcome, O Truly Awakened One. Please be so gracious as to sojourn in this palace.” Then the Buddha, accepting the invitation, ascended to the precious hall. This also took place in the same way everywhere in the ten directions.

de nas lha'i rgyal po rab mtshe mas sngon gyi de bzhin gshegs pa dgra bcom pa yang dag par rdzogs pa'i sangs rgyas rnams la dge ba'i rtsa ba ji ltar bskyed pa de rjes su dran nas sangs rgyas kyi byin gyi rlabs kyis de'i tshe tshigs su bcad pa 'di dag smras so/ /
Then the celestial king, reflecting on the roots of goodness he had planted with past Buddhas, spoke these verses with the aid of the Buddha’s spiritual powers:

bkra shis dam pa gang zhig gis/ / sangs rgyas grags pa'i dam par mtshan btags mtshan gsol ba/ / nor bu gtsug tu gshegs pa ltar/ / des ni 'dir yang bkra shis mchog gyur cig /
bkra shis dam pa gang zhig gis; ; 'jig rten sgron ma blo zhes mtshan btags pa/ / sbyangs pa'i lam du gshegs pa ltar/ / des ni 'dir yang bkra shis mchog gyur cig /
bkra shis dam pa gang zhig gis; ; bsgribs med gzigs pa 'dzum pa'i spyan du mtshan btags pa/ / rgyan gcig ldan par gshegs pa ltar/ / nges ni 'dir yang bkra shis mchog gyur cig /
bkra shis dam pa gang zhig gis/ / 'jig rten sgron ma mar me mdzad ces mtshan btags pa/ / rnam par rgyal par gshegs pa ltar/ / des ni 'dir yang bkra shis mchog gyur cig /
bkra shis dam pa gang zhig gis/ / bde gshegs yang dag don gzigs pa zhas mtshan btags pa/ / dri med rtse mor gshegs pa ltar/ / des ni 'dir yang bkra shis mchog gyur cig /
bkra shis dam pa gang zhig gis/ / de bzhin gshegs pa rang byung mchog ces mtshan btags pa/ / rin chen spos su gshegs pa ltar; ; des ni 'dir yang bkra shis mchog gyur cig /
bkra shis dam pa gang zhig gis/ / 'jig rten sgron ma dbyig gi lha zhes mtshan btags pa/ / dri med sna tshogs gshegs pa ltar/ / des ni 'dir yang bkra shis mchog gyur cig /
bkra shis dam pa gang zhig gis/ / 'gro ba med pa smra ba'i stag ces mtshan btags pa/ / thams cad tshul du gshegs pa ltar/ / des ni 'dir yang bkra shis mchog gyur cig /
bkra shis dam pa gang zhig gis/ / yon tan kun mnga' dpal gyis rgyal bar mtshan btags pa; ; dga' ba'i rgyan du gshegs pa ltar/ / des ni 'dir yang bkra shis mchog gyur cig /
bkra shis dam pa gang zhig gis/ / 'jig rten phan brtson dka' thub drag por mtshan btags pa/ / kun nas mdog tu gshegs pa ltar/ / des ni 'dir yang bkra shis mchog gyur cig /

The Buddha Renown, famed throughout the ten directions, Supreme among the Auspicious, Has been in this hall of jewels; Therefore this place is most auspicious.
The Buddha Jewel King, lamp of the world, Supreme among the Auspicious, Has been in this pure hall; Therefore this place is most auspicious.
The Buddha Joyful Eye, with unhindered vision, Supreme among the Auspicious, Has been in this adorned hall; Therefore this place is most auspicious.
The Buddha Burning Lamp, lighting the world, Supreme among the Auspicious, Has been in this magnificent hall; Therefore this place is most auspicious.
The Buddha Benefactor, aid of the world, Supreme among the Auspicious, Has been in this undefiled hall; Therefore this place is most auspicious.
The Buddha Well Aware, who had no teacher, Supreme among the Auspicious, Has been in this hall of precious fragrance; Therefore this place is most auspicious.
The Buddha Surpassing the Gods, a lamp in the world, Supreme among the Auspicious, Has been in this hall of sublime fragrance; Therefore this place is most auspicious.
The Buddha No Departure, hero of philosophy, Supreme among the Auspicious, Has been in this hall of the universal eye; Therefore this place is most auspicious.
The Buddha Unsurpassed, replete with all virtues, Supreme among the Auspicious, Has been in this well-adorned hall; Therefore this place is most auspcious.
The Buddha Ascetic, benefiting the world, Supreme among the Auspicious, Has been in this hall of universal embellishment; Therefore this place is most auspicious.

ji ltar lha'i rgyal po rab mtshe mas sangs rgyas kyi byin gyi rlabs kyis sngon gyi rgyal ba'i gshegs pa brjod de mngon par bstod pa de bzhin du 'jig rten gyi khams thams cad kyi rgyal po rab mtshe ma rnams kyang sangs rgyas kyi byin gyi rlabs kyis sngon gyi yang dag par rdzogs pa'i sangs rgyas gshegs pa brjod cing glu'i dbyangs kyis tshigs su bcad de mngon par bstod do/ /

Just as the king of the Suyama heaven in this world, graced with the occult power of the Buddha, recalled the virtues of Buddhas of ancient times and extolled them, so did all the kings of the Suyama heavens in the ten directions laud the virtues of Buddhas.

de nas bcom ldan 'das khang pa nor bu sna tshogs su gshegs nas gang na bting ba la skyil mo krung bcas te bzhugs so/ / ji ltar bcom ldan 'das bzhugs pa de bzhin du 'jig rten gyi khams thams cad du'ang gdan bting ba de dag la bzhugs par snang ngo/ / bcom ldan 'das bzhugs ma thag tu khang pa nor bu sna tshogs de/ 'di lta ste/ dper na/ rab mtshe ma'i lha'i ris thams cad tsam du che bar gyur par snang ste/ 'di na ji lta ba bzhin du 'jig rten gyi khams thams cad na yang de bzhin no/ /

Then the World Honored One entered the jewel-adorned hall and sat crosslegged on the jewel lotus flower bank lion throne; the hall suddenly expanded vastly. The same thing happened in all worlds of the ten directions as happened in the abodes of the gods.
shin tu rgyas pa chen po'i mdo/ sangs rgyas phal po che zhes bya ba las/ rab mtshe ma'i gnas rnam par 'phrul ba'i le'u zhes bya ba ste/ nyi shu bzhi pa'o// //
[25. rab mtshe ma'i gnas su byang chub sems dpa' 'dus pas tshigs su bcad pa bstan pa'i le'u]
BOOK TWENTY. Eulogies in the Palace of the Suyama Heaven

de nas sangs rgyas kyi mthus phyogs bcu nas byang chub sems dpa' mang po lhags par gyur te/ byang chub sems dpa' re re zhing yang 'khor sangs rgyas kyi zhing brgya phrag stong gi rdul shin tu phra ba snyed dang lhan cig tu 'ongs te byang chub sems dpa' re re zhing yang byang chub sems dpa' sangs rgyas kyi zhing gi rdul shin tu phra ba snyed dang lhan gcig tu phyin to/ / byang chub sems dpa' de dag thams cad kyang ming 'di zhes bya ba dag ste/ 'di ltar yon tan dang ldan pa dang / blo gros dang ldan pa dang / dpal dang ldan pa dang / dga' ba dang ldan pa dang / khrel dang ldan pa dang / brtson 'grus dang ldan pa dang / stobs dang ldan pa dang / rig pa dang ldan pa dang / blo dang ldan pa dang / ye shes dang ldan pa dag go/ byang chub sems dpa' de dag thams cad kyang 'jig rten gyi khams ming 'di zhes bya ba dag nas 'ongs pa ste/ 'di ltar gnyen dang ldan pa dang / me tog dang ldan pa dang / nor dang ldan pa dang / dpal dang ldan pa dang / sgron ma dang ldan pa dang / rdo rje dang ldan pa dang / bde ba dang ldan pa dang / nyi ma dang ldan pa dang / dge ba dang ldan pa dang / tshangs pa dang ldan pa dag go /byang chub sems dpa' de dag thams cad kyang de bzhin gshegs pa'i mtshan 'di zhes bya ba dag gi zham 'bring na tshangs par spyod pa dag ste/ 'di ltar nyams pa med pa'i spyan dang / gzhan ma yin pa'i spyan dang / mi g.yo ba'i spyan dang / mi bskyod pa'i spyan dang / chu'i spyan dang / bcings pa med pa'i spyan dang / kun tu spyod pa'i spyan dang / 'od kyi spyan dang / dam pa'i spyan dang / mthon mthing gi spyan dag go /

THEN, DUE TO THE SPIRITUAL FORCE of the Buddha, a great enlightening being from each of the ten directions, each accompanied by as many enlightening beings as atoms in a buddha-land, came from beyond as many lands as atoms in a hundred thousand buddha-lands, and gathered in an assembly. The names of those great enlightening beings were: Forest of Virtues; Forest of Wisdom; Forest of Victory; Forest of Fearlessness; Forest of Conscience; Forest of Energy; Forest of Power; Forest of Practice; Forest of Awareness; Forest of Knowledge. The lands which these enlightening beings came from were called: Intimate Wisdom; Symbolic Wisdom; Jewel Wisdom; Supreme Wisdom; Lamp Wisdom; Adamantine Wisdom; Peaceful Wisdom; Sun Wisdom; Clear Wisdom; Pure Wisdom. These enlightening beings had each purely cultivated religious practice in the company of a Buddha; the names of those Buddhas were: Eternal Eye; Invincible Eye; Nondwelling Eye; Imperturbable Eye; Divine Eye; Eye of Liberation; Eye Comprehending Truth; Eye Understanding Forms; Supreme Eye; Violet Eye.

de nas byang chub sems dpa' de dag bcom ldan 'das la phyag 'tshal nas sangs rgyas kyi mthus phyogs bcu rgyas par byas te/ gang nas 'ongs pa'i phyogs su brten nas seng+ge'i khri rin po che'i snying po can dag bshams te skyil mo krung bcas nas 'khod do/ / ji ltar gling bzhi pa 'dir rab mtshe ma'i gnas su byang chub sems dpa' 'ongs par gyur pa de bzhin du 'jig rten gyi khams thams cad kyi gling bzhi pa kun tu yang rab mtshe ma'i gnas kyi khang pa nor bu sna tshogs su'ang lhags par gyur te/ byang chub sems dpa'i ming yang de skad ces bya ba sha stag/ de bzhin gshegs pa'i mtshan kyang de skad ces bya ba'i zham 'bring na tshangs par spyod pa sha stag go/

Having come to the Buddha, these enlightening beings bowed at the Buddha’s feet, then each made jewel bank lion seats in their respective directions and sat thereupon. As in this world enlightening beings gathered this way in the Suyama heaven, so did this also take place in all worlds; the names of the enlightening beings, their worlds, and the Buddhas they associated with, were all the same.

de nas bcom ldan 'das kyi zhabs kyi bol gnyis nas 'od zer bye ba brgya stong bkye ste/ phyogs bcu thams cad snang bar byas nas 'jig rten gyi khams thams cad bstan te/ byang chub sems dpa' de dag gis 'jig rten gyi khams thams cad kyi gling bzhi pa kun gyi rab mtshe ma'i gnas thams cad na yang de bzhin gshegs pa'i rnam par 'phrul pa yod pa mthong ngo/ /

Then the World Honored One emanated from the top of his feet ten trillion beams of light of wonderful hues, illumining the ten directions; the Buddhas and congregations in the palaces of the Suyama heavens in all worlds were made clearly visible.
de nas byang chub sems dpa' yon tan dang ldan pas sangs rgyas kyi mthus phyogs bcur rnam par bltas te/ de'i tshe tshigs su bcad pa 'di dag smras so/ /
Then the Enlightening being Forest of Virtues, imbued with power from the Buddha, looked over the ten directions and said in verse,

sangs rgyas 'od zer 'od snang bas/ / phyogs rnams thams cad rnam par snang / / des ni rab tu gsal byas pas/ / mig la rab rib gang yang med/ /
mtshe ma rab kyi gnas 'di na/ / gang zag dam pa sangs rgyas bzhugs/ / de bzhin kun na'ang gsal bar snang / / de ni 'jig rten ngo mtshar to/ /
sems can gtso bo bcu yi rnams/ / gshegs par gyur pa mngon par ston/ / de dag 'khor kyang ci 'dra ba/ / de bzhin kun na rab tu snang / /
phyogs rnams bcu po thams cad na/ / chos kyi dam pa rab tu ston/ / de kun ming yang de bzhin te/ / bdag cag rnams kyi kun rdzob bzhin/ /
'jig rten khams kyi ming dag kyang / / de zhes bya ba kun nas 'ongs/ / gang zag dam pa de dag ni/ / tshangs pa'i spyod pa'ang de na spyod/ /
bdag cag rnams la gang btags pa/ / kun gyi ming yang de dang mthun/ / sangs rgyas zhing rnams mthun ldan pa/ / de dag sangs rgyas rnam 'phrul pa'o/ /
mi yi 'jig rten kun na yang / / 'di na rgyal ba bzhugs par shes/ / gzhan gyis de yi rgyal po yi/ / gnas na de bzhin bzhugs pa mthong / /
'jig rten khams rnams thams cad na/ / gang zag dam pa de bzhugs kyang / / rgyal ba mtshe ma rab gnas na/ / bzhugs par bdag cag kun kyang sems/ /
'jig rten khams rnams thams cad na/ / sangs rgyas gzi brjid bsam mi khyab/ / de dag smon lam bskul ba'i phyir; ; 'jig rten thams cad su rab tu bkye/ /
sems can gtso bo'i rnam 'phrul ba/ / 'di dag de rnams kun gyis mthong / / sangs rgyas yon tan mtha' yas te/ / 'jig rten zang zing thub pas spangs/ /
phyogs rnams thams cad kun tu byung / / chags pa med pa nam mkha' bzhin/ / de ni gcig las shin tu 'das/ / mang po dag tu'ang mi dmigs so/ /
mtha' yas legs mnga' sangs rgyas rnams/ / de dag shes par ji ltar rung / / gnas pa med cing len pa med/ / chos dbyings rtogs par thugs su chud/ /

Buddha emanates great light Illumining the ten directions; All see the Honored One of heaven and earth Freely, without obstruction.
Buddha sits in the Suyama palace Yet pervades all worlds in the cosmos; This phenomenon is most extraordinary, Wondered at by the world.
The king of the Suyama heaven Has praised ten Buddhas in verse; What is seen in this assembly Is all the same everywhere.
Those groups of enlightening beings All have the same names as ours: In every place in the ten directions They expound the unsurpassed teaching.
The worlds from which they come Are also the same in name as ours: Each of them have, with their Buddhas, Perfected religious practice.
The names of each of those Buddhas Are also the same as of ours; Their countries are rich and happy, Their spiritual powers are autonomous.
Everywhere in the ten directions They think the Buddha’s there; Some see him in the human world, Some see him in heaven.
The Buddha abides everywhere In all the various lands: We now see the Buddha In this celestial court.
He made a vow of enlightenment That extended to every world in the cosmos; This is why Buddha’s power Pervades all inconceivably.
Leaving behind worldly desires He fulfilled boundless virtue; Therefore he gained spiritual power And is seen by all beings.
He traverses all worlds in the cosmos Like space, with no obstruction; One body, infinite bodies: His form cannot be grasped.
Buddha’s virtues are boundless; How could they be measured? Neither abiding nor leaving, He permeates the cosmos.
de nas byang chub sems dpa' blo gros dang ldan pas sangs rgyas kyi byin gyi rlabs kyis phyogs bcur rnam par bltas te/ de'i tshe tshigs su bcad pa 'di dag smras so/ /
Then the enlightening being Forest of Wisdom, empowered by the Buddha, looked over the ten directions and said in verse,

'jig rten mgon po 'phrul chen rnams/ / rdul med gang zag dam pa dag / 'dus shing tshogs pa bsam yas pa'i/ / bskal pa dag tu shin tu dkon/ /
de dag thams cad kun gzigs pa/ / sems can gtso bo 'od mdzad de/ / srog chags kun la phan pa'i phyir/ / sems can rnams la chos ston to/ /
'jig rten mun nag 'di dag tu/ / 'jig rten mgon po byung gyur pa/ / 'jig rten sgron ma de dag ni/ / blta bar shin tu dka' ba yin/ /
sbyin pa tshul khrims bzod pa'i rab/ / brtson 'grus bsam gtan sgom pa dang / / shes rab sngon chad spyad pas na; ; 'gro ba thams cad snang bar mdzad/ /
sangs rgyas 'dra ba gang yang med/ / de phyir de dang mnyam pa med/ / chos rnams yod pa ma yin pas/ / skyes bu'i dam pa mthong ba med/ /
sangs rgyas shes rab chen po rnams/ / mtshan gyi tshogs ni bsam mi khyab/ / sku yi tshogs kyis shin tu 'phags/ / chos rnams kun gyis yang dag byung / /
'jig rten grags chen dam pa'i rnams/ / dpa' bo chen po de dag snang / / de dag mtshan tsam thos pas kyang / / ngan song thams cad spangs par 'gyur/ /
bskal pa rnams ni brjod med par/ / byang chub don du 'khor byas kyang / / 'di yi tshul ni ma shes na/ / byang chub don du bzhugs pa min/ /
sangs rgyas bsam gyis mi khyab pa/ / bskal pa bye bar bkur ba dang / / gang gis tshul 'di bsam pa gnyis/ / 'di ni de las khyad du 'phags/ /
gang gis brjod yas zhing gi rnams/ / rin chen gang ste thub gsol kyang / / 'di yi tshul ni ma shes na/ / sangs rgyas byang chub de la ring / /

The great leader of the world, Supreme honored one, free from defilement, Is hard to get to meet Even in countless eons.
Buddha emits great light Visible to all the world; Preaching extensively for the multitudes, He benefits all living beings.
Buddha appears in the world Removing the darkness of ignorance; Such a lamp of the world Is rare and hard to get to behold.
Having cultivated generosity, self-control, and patience, Diligence and meditation, And ultimate transcendent wisdom, With them he lights the world.
The Buddha has no peer; None comparable can be found. Without comprehending real truth No one can perceive him.
Buddha’s body and psychic powers Are inconceivably free: Neither going nor coming, He speaks the truth to liberate.
If any can see and hear The pure Teacher of humans and gods, They’ll leave forever the states of woe And cast off all miseries.
For measureless, countless eons He cultivated enlightening practice; Who cannot know the meaning of this Cannot attain buddhahood.
If one can know this meaning, One’s virtues will surpass One who makes offerings to countless Buddhas For inconceivable eons.
Even if one gives to a Buddha Countless lands full of jewels, If one knows not this meaning, One never attains enlightenment.
de nas byang chub sems dpa' dpal dang ldan pas sangs rgyas kyi byin gyi rlabs kyis phyogs bcur rnam par bltas te/ de'i tshe tshigs su bcad pa 'di dag smras so/ /
Then the enlightening being Forest of Victory, imbued with power from the Buddha, looked over the ten directions and said in verse,

nam mkha' dri ma med pa la/ / nyi ma'i 'od zer mtha' yas pas/ / dpyid kyi zla ba tha ma la/ / phyogs bcu dag tu rab tu snang / /
de tshe smig rgyu ci 'dra ba/ / de dag bgrang bar mi nus te/ / mig can rnams kyang de la rmongs/ / long ba rnams kyi spyod yul min/ /

gang tshe 'jig rten zhing yin par/ / tshul bzhin du ni rtogs byed na/ / de tshe thams cad don bstan pa/ / byang chub sems dpas rab tu shes/ /

As in the summer months With the sky clear and cloudless, The radiant sun blazes with light Filling the ten directions,
That light boundless, Impossible to measure Even by those with eyes, Let alone the blind—
So are the Buddhas— Their virtues are boundless; Even in inconceivable eons No one can know them in detail.
All things have no provenance And no one can create them: There is nowhere whence they are born, They cannot be discriminated.
All things have no provenance, Therefore they have no birth; Because there is no birth, Neither can extinction be found.
All things are birthless And have no extinction either; Those who understand in this way Will see the Buddha.
Because things have no birth, Their inherent nature is nonexistent; One who analyzes and knows this Will arrive at the profound truth.
Because things have no inherent nature No one can comprehend them; When understanding things in this way, Ultimately nothing is understood.
That which is said to have birth Is to manifest lands— If one can know the nature of lands One’s mind will not be confused:
Examining according to truth The nature of the world and lands, If one is able to know this, One can explain all things.
de nas byang chub sems dpa' dga' ba dang ldan pas sangs rgyas kyi mthus phyogs bcur rnam par bltas te; de'i tshe tshigs su bcad pa 'di dag smras so/ /
Then the enlightening being Forest of Fearlessness, by the power of the Buddha, looked over the ten directions and said in verse,

gnas 'di shin tu rgya che ste/ / chos kyi dbyings kyis klas pa yin/ / rtag tu kun tu song ba ste/ / yid du 'ong zhing gnas kyang med; ;
de la yang dag brtags byas shing / / rim gro yod par dad byed na/ / sdug bsngal nam yang mi mthong ste/ / ngan song rnams kyang mi mthong ngo/ /
tshad med de bzhin grangs med pa'i/ / 'jig rten khams su su 'gro bas/ / gang rnams 'di na snang ba yi/ / sangs rgyas byin rlabs thos par 'gyur/ /
drang srong chen po'i byin gyi rlabs/ / gang gis thos par gyur nas kyang / / 'di 'dra sangs rgyas chos so zhes/ / rtog med bla med byang chub bo/ /
gang rnams 'das pa'i sangs rgyas kyis/ / chos nyid la ni yid ches pa; ; de kun 'jig rten sgron ma ste/ / rkang gnyis ldan pa'i dam par 'gyur/ /
sangs rgyas rnam par 'phrul ba 'di/ / la la zhig gis thos gyur cing / / thos nas dad par byed gyur na/ / de dag mi yi dam par 'gyur/ /

bskal pa bsam gyis mi khyab par/ / 'di 'dra thos pa shin tu dkon/ / smon lam dbang ni ma gtogs par/ / blo gros 'di 'drar 'gyur ba min; ;
sangs rgyas dam chos 'di las kyang / / legs par bshad pa bzung byas shing / / gzhan la ston par su byed pa/ / de dag bsam gyis mi khyab 'gyur/ /
de la brtson 'grus bskyed byas shing / / yid la go cha bgo byas te/ / gang las sangs rgyas brjod pa yi/ / shes pa 'di 'dra mnyan par bya/ /

The Buddha’s immense body Reaches the extremities of the cosmos; Without leaving this seat It pervades all places.
Whoever, hearing this teaching, Respects and has faith in it, Shall forever escape all the miseries Of the states of woe.
Even going to many worlds, Uncountably numerous, Single-mindedly desiring to hear Of the powers of the Buddha,
And such qualities of Buddhas, Their unexcelled enlightenment, Even wanting to hear for a moment, None is able to do so.
If any in the past Believed this aspect of Buddha, They have already become Buddhas And are lamps of the world.
If any will get to hear Of the Buddha’s free powers, And having heard will believe, They too will become Buddhas.
If any in the present Can believe this teaching of Buddha, They will also become Buddhas And expound the teaching fearlessly.
This teaching is hard to encounter Even in countless eons: If any get to hear it, Know it is the power of past vows.
If any can accept and hold Such teachings of Buddha, And, upholding them, spread them too, They will become Buddhas.
How much the more so those who work diligently, Firm of mind, not giving up: You should know such people Will certainly attain enlightenment.
de nas byang chub sems dpa' khrel dang ldan pas sangs rgyas kyi byin gyi rlabs kyis phyogs bcur rnam par bltas te/ de'i tshe tshigs su bcad pa 'di dag smras so/ /
Then the enlightening being Forest of Conscience, empowered by the Buddha, looked over the ten directions and said in verse,

gang zhig thos nas 'di 'dra ba'i/ / dga' ba yangs pa skye ba dang / / the tshom rnam par gcad pa ni/ / 'jig rten na ni ngo mtshar che/ /
'di ltar thams cad gzigs pa'i rnams/ / nyid kyis 'gro la bka' stsal na/ / sangs rgyas mi mkhyen gang yang med/ / de ltar sangs rgyas bsam mi khyab/ /
mi shes pa yi rgyu las ni/ / ye shes 'jug par mi 'gyur te/ / mun pa'i mthu dang snang ba gnyis/ / lhan cig 'byung bar mi 'gyur bstan/ /

'khor dang mya ngan 'das pa dag / ji ltar med las brtags pa ltar/ / de bzhin shes dang mi shes pa/ / mtshan nyid bzhin du dmigs pa med/ /

ji ltar lus dang rnam shes pa/ / gzhan dang gzhan las 'byung 'gyur ba/ / de bzhin shes dang mi shes gnyis/ / 'grogs par 'gyur ba nam yang med/ /
ji ltar dug la phan pa'i rtsi/ / 'phral du dug ni dug min byed/ / de ltar shes pa mi shes pas/ / shin tu sel ba byed par brjod/ /
sangs rgyas bla na gang yang med/ / de dang 'dra ba'ang yod pa min/ / de las gzhan du 'gyur ba med/ / de bas rgyal ba shin tu dkon/ /

If people get to hear This rare teaching of freedom And can produce a joyful mind They’ll soon remove the webs of doubt.
The one who knows and sees all Speaks these words himself; There’s nothing the Buddha knows not, Therefore he’s inconceivable.
Never from lack of wisdom Has wisdom ever been born: Worldlings are always in the dark, And therefore none can produce it.
Just as form and nonform Are two and not one, So are knowledge and ignorance: They are essentially different.
As signs and signlessness, Birth-death and nirvana, Are distinct and not the same, So are knowledge and nescience.
When a world first comes to be There’s no sign of decay: So it is with knowledge and ignorance: Their characteristics are not simultaneous.
Like the enlightening beings’ first state of mind Does not coexist with their final state of mind, So it is with knowledge and nescience: These two minds do not coexist.
Just as bodies of consciousness Are individual and don’t combine, So also knowledge and ignorance Ultimately have no communion.
Just as a panacea Can eliminate all toxins, So also can knowledge Extinguish all ignorance.
The Enlightened is unexcelled And also has no peer; He has no compare at all And is therefore hard to meet.
de nas byang chub sems dpa' brtson 'grus dang ldan pas sangs rgyas kyi mthus phyogs bcur rnam par bltas te/ de'i tshe tshigs su bcad de smras pa/ chos rnams 'di dag 'gal med par/ /
Then the enlightening being Forest of Energy, empowered by the Buddha, looked over the ten directions and said in verse,

mkhyen nas sangs rgyas thugs su chud/ / des ni mi mkhyen gang yang med/ / ye shes kyi yang pha rol phyin/ / ji ltar gser dang sa le sbram; ;
ngo bo nyid kyis 'gal ba med/ / de ltar chos min de bzhin chos/ / de dag thams cad mtshan nyid gcig / sems can sems can ma yin pa/ /
ngo bo nyid kyis rang bzhin med; ; gdags su med las byung ba ltar/ / chos rnams rang bzhin de bzhin no/ / ma 'ongs dus ni ji lta bur/ /
'das pas brjod par bya ba ste/ / de la mtshan nyid yod pa min/ / de bzhin chos la mtshan nyid med/ / 'brel bar skye dang 'gag pa dang / /

mang po'i tshul du bgrang ba yis/ / dngos po grangs med 'gyur ba yang / / blo yi rnam pa tha dad bstan/ / 'jig rten khams rnams la la dag /
bsam gyis mi khyab tshig gyur kyang / / nam mkha' 'jig par 'gyur ba med/ / rang byung ye shes de bzhin no/ / ji ltar 'jig rten phyogs bcu yi/ /
nam mkha' so sor brtags pa ltar/ / de bzhin sangs rgyas rnams mthong ste/ / sangs rgyas rnams la rtog mi mnga'; ;

All things have no differentiation; No one can know them: Only among Buddhas are they known, Because Buddhas’ knowledge is ultimate.
Just as gold and gold color Are in essence no different, So also phenomena and nonphenomena Are in essence no different.
Sentient beings and not sentient beings Are both without reality: In this way the natures of all things In truth are nonexistent.
Just as the future Has not the marks of the past, So also do all things Not have any marks at all.
Just as the signs of birth and death Are all unreal, So also are all things Void of intrinsic nature.
Nirvana cannot be grasped, But when spoken of there are two kinds, So it is of all things: When discriminated, they are different.
Just as based on something counted There exists a way of counting, Their nature is nonexistent: Thus are phenomena perfectly known.
It’s like the method of counting, Adding one, up to infinity; The numbers have no substantial nature: They are distinguished due to intellect.
Just as the worlds have an end When burnt in the final holocaust Yet space is not destroyed: So is the Buddha’s knowledge.
These sentient beings of the universe Each grasp characteristics of space: So it is of the Buddhas; Worldlings conceive of them arbitrarily.
de nas byang chub sems dpa' stobs dang ldan pas sangs rgyas kyi mthus phyogs bcu rnam par bltas te/ de'i tshe tshigs su bcad de smras pa/ ji ltar dus rnams gsum po yis/ /
Then the enlightening being Forest of Power, by the Buddha’s power, looked over the ten directions and said in verse,

sems can khams rnams brjod par 'gyur/ / sems can de dag thams cad kyang / / phung po lnga las shin tu brjod/ / de rnams las kyi phung chen yin; ;
las kyi rtsa ba'ang sems yin te/ / sems ni sgyu ma bzhin du bshad/ / sgyu mar gyur pa 'gro 'di'o/ / gang na 'jig rten 'di 'byung zhing / /
yang na ldog par 'gyur ba yi/ / 'jig rten 'jig rten mi byed de/ / gzhan gyi rgyus kyang byas pa min/ / 'jig rten 'di na 'byung ba 'byung / /
'jig rten 'dir yang ldog par 'gyur/ / 'byung zhes brjod par mi bya ste; ; de ni 'jig rten zhes pa yin/ / gang la 'jig rten snang ba zhes/ /
'du shes rnam par brtags pa yi/ / 'jig rten zhes bya gang zhig yin/ / snang ba zhes bya'ang ci zhig yin/ / dus gsum dag tu rgyu ba yi/ /
phung po 'di ni 'jig rten yin/ / de dag 'gog pa snang ba zhes/ / 'gro ba dag tu 'du shes 'gyur/ / phung po zhes bya 'di ni ci/ /
phung po'i rang bzhin ji lta bu/ / phung po rnams ni mi 'jig phyir/ / dngos po med ces rab tu brjod/ / phung po 'di dag rnam brtags don/ /

sangs rgyas chos kyang de bzhin no/ / sangs rgyas chos dang sangs rgyas rnams/ / ngo bo nyid kyis rang bzhin med/ / ma nor yang dag ji bzhin pa'i/ /
chos nyid 'di ni rtogs gyur nas/ / kun gzigs thams cad mkhyen pa yi/ / sangs rgyas kun nas rab tu snang / /

All realms of living beings Are in the past, present, or future: The living beings of past, present, and future All dwell in the five clusters.
The five clusters are based on actions, Actions are based on mind: Mental phenomena are like phantoms, And so indeed is the world.
The world doesn’t make itself, Nor is it made by another: Yet it has a formation And also has a disintegration.
Though the world has a formation And a disintegration, One who understands the world Would not speak this way.
What is the world, What is not a world? World and not world Are only distinctions of name.
The three times and five clusters Are called the world, Their extinction is “not the world”: Thus they are just temporary names.
How are the clusters explained? What nature do they have? The nature of the clusters is indestructible, So it is called unborn.
Analyzing these clusters, Their nature is fundamentally empty and nil; Because it is empty, it cannot be destroyed: This is the meaning of birthlessness.
Since sentient beings are thus, So also are the Buddhas; Buddhas and Buddha-teachings Intrinsically have no existence.
If any can know these things Truly, without delusion, The one who knows and sees all Will always be before them.
de nas byang chub sems dpa' rig pa dang ldan pas sangs rgyas kyi mthus phyogs bcur rnam par bltas nas de'i tshe tshigs su bcad de smras pa/ rang bzhin dngos po med pa yi; ;
Then the enlightening being Forest of Practice, empowered by the Buddha, looked over the ten directions and said in verse,

'jig rten khams rnams thams cad kyi/ / sa yi khams rnams ji bzhin te/ / sangs rgyas rnam 'phrul ngo mtshar che/ / de yi rang bzhin 'di yin la/ /
brjod cing bsngags pa mtha' yas te/ / 'das pa'i 'jig rten khams rnams su/ / sus kyang brjod pa ma yin no/ / gzhan du sems can las kyis na/ /
shin tu bstan par brjod pa ste/ / sems can rnams ni ma gtogs par/ / las zhes bya ba ci mi dmigs/ / de bzhin stong pa'i las kyis kyang / /
brjod pa rnams ni tshad med par/ / sems can kun gyi las su gyur/ / de la 'ongs pa gang yang med/ / ji ltar kha dog dbyibs kyi rnams/ /
las kyi rgyu ni bsam mi khyab/ / snang yang de dag de na med/ / rnam par rig pa'i dngos nyid 'dra/ / de bzhin sems can gtso bo yi/ /
sku ni bsam gyis mi khyab pa/ / brjod pa rnams kyang tshad med par/ / zhing rnams kun na rab tu snang / / skus ni rdzogs pa'i sangs rgyas min/ /
sangs rgyas rnams la sku mi mnga'/ / dpa' bo chen po chos sku ste/ / chos kun rtogs par thugs su chud/ / gang gis rang byung rnams kyi sku/ /
yang dag ji bzhin mthong ba ni/ / sangs rgyas chos ni rnam kun dang / / chos rnams la yang rmongs pa med/ / 'das par gyur pa'i chos rnams kun/ /
mya ngan 'das par shes gyur na/ / de dag shin tu mi gnas pa'i/ / rdzogs pa'i sangs rgyas mthong ba yin/ / yang dag sangs rgyas sus mthong zhing / /
dran pa shin tu bsgoms byas te/ / mtshan med tha dad med pa rnams/ / de dag chos kyi rgyal po'i sras/ /

As in all worlds All the solid elements Have no independent existence Yet are found everywhere,
So also does the Buddha-body Pervade all worlds, Its various physical forms Without abode or origin.
Just because of activities Do we say the name “living beings”— And there is no action to be found Apart from living beings.
The nature of action is fundamentally empty and nil, But is that on which beings are based, Everywhere producing all physical forms, And yet coming from nowhere.
This is the active power of forms, Impossible to conceive: If one comprehends the basis, Therein no object is seen.
The Buddha-body is also like this: It cannot be conceived; Its various physical forms Appear in all lands in the cosmos.
The body is not the Buddha, Nor is Buddha a body: Only reality is the body, Permeating all things.
If one can see the Buddha-body Pure as the nature of reality, Such a one has no doubt Or confusion about the Buddha.
If one sees all things As in essence like nirvana, This is seeing the Enlightened Ultimately without abode.
If one cultivates right awareness And clearly sees true awakening, Signless, without discrimination, This is an inheritor of truth.
de nas byang chub sems dpa' blo dang ldan pas sangs rgyas kyi mthus phyogs bcur rnam par bltas te/ de'i tshe tshigs su bcad de smras pa/ ji ltar ri mo'i las rnams la/ /
Then the enlightening being Forest of Awareness, imbued with the power of Buddha, looked over the ten directions and said in verse,

tshon rnams sna tshogs kun 'du ba/ / kun kyang 'byung ba chen por mnyam/ / sems kyis yongs su brtags pa yin/ / khams la tshon rtsi de dag med; ;
tshon rtsi la yang khams med de/ / khams rnams ma gtogs gzhan na yang / / tshon ces bya ba gang yang med/ / sems la ri mo de med de/ /
ri mo la'ang sems med do; ; sems de ma gtogs gzhan du yang / / ri mo gang yang mi dmigs so/ / sems de rtag pa ma yin pa/ /
bsam gyis mi khyab tshad med cing / / phan tshun shes pa med pa yi/ / gzugs rnams thams cad ston par byed/ / ji ltar ri mo mkhan gyi rnams/ /
sems ni gang gis ri mo de/ / bris pa'i sems kyang mi shes pa/ / de bzhin chos kyi rang bzhin no/ / sems ni ri mo mkhan dang 'dra/ /
sems ni phung po byed pa ste/ / 'jig rten khams na ji snyed pa'i/ / 'jig rten 'di dag sems kyis bris/ / sems dang 'dra ba sangs rgyas te/ /
sangs rgyas ji bzhin 'gro ba'o/ / sems dang sangs rgyas dag la yang / / ngo bo nyid kyis zad pa med/ / sems kyi rgyud rnams ci 'dra ba/ /
de dag sangs rgyas rab tu mkhyen/ / de phyir sangs rgyas rang bzhin gyis; ; 'gro ba sna tshogs gyur par snang / / lus kyi rnams la sems med de/ /
sems la'ang lus rnams yod pa min/ / sangs rgyas mdzad pa'ang rab tu byed/ / de ltar spyod pa ngo mtshar che; ; gang zhig dus gsum thams cad kyi/ /
rgyal ba thams cad shes 'dod na/ / sangs rgyas thams cad sems kyi dngos/ / chos kyi dbyings su blta bar gyis/ /

It’s like a painter Spreading the various colors: Delusion grasps different forms But the elements have no distinctions.
In the elements there’s no form, And no form in the elements; And yet apart from the elements No form can be found.
In the mind is no painting, In painting there is no mind; Yet not apart from mind Is any painting to be found.
That mind never stops, Manifesting all forms, Countless, inconceivably many, Unknown to one another.
Just as a painter Can’t know his own mind Yet paints due to the mind, So is the nature of all things.
Mind is like an artist, Able to paint the worlds: The five clusters all are born thence; There’s nothing it doesn’t make.
As is the mind, so is the Buddha; As the Buddha, so living beings: Know that Buddha and mind Are in essence inexhaustible.
If people know the actions of mind Create all the worlds, They will see the Buddha And understand Buddha’s true nature.
Mind does not stay in the body, Nor body stay in mind: Yet it’s able to perform Buddha-work Freely, without precedent.
If people want to really know All Buddhas of all times, They should contemplate the nature of the cosmos: All is but mental construction.
de nas byang chub sems dpa' ye shes dang ldan pas sangs rgyas kyi mthus phyogs bcur rnam par bltas te/ de'i tshe tshigs su bcad de smras pa/ gzung du med la 'dzin ces bya/ /
Then the enlightening being Forest of Knowledge, receiving power from the Buddha, looked over the ten directions and said in verse,

snang ba med pa snang ba ste; ; mnyan du med par nyan par byed/ / sems med pa yi sems dang ldan/ / tshad med pa la tshad ma yis/ /
gang zhig 'dzin par mi 'dod pa/ / de ni tshad med tshad ma yis/ / nam yang 'dzin par mi 'gyur ro/ / brjod du med pa smra byed pa/ /
bdag la shin tu slu ba ste/ / de yi don kyang rjod mi byed/ / srog chags rnams kyang tshim mi 'gyur/ / de bzhin mtha' yas brjod ldan pa'i/ /
brjod pa gang zhig smra 'dod pa/ / bskal pa grangs med zad byas kyang / / rang byung rnams kyis brjod mi zad/ / yid bzhin nor bu dag pa ni/ /
kha dog kun tu rab tu snang / / de la kha dog yod pa min/ / sangs rgyas yon tan de bzhin no/ / ji ltar nam mkha' dri med cing / /
gzugs med bstan du med yin yang / / gzugs rnams thams cad ston par byed/ / nam mkha' snang ba gang yang med/ / de bzhin thams cad gzigs pa rnams/ /
yon tan kun dang ldan ston kyang / / de ni sus kyang mthong ba med/ / sems la'ang de ni mi gnas so/ / sangs rgyas sgra ni grags mod kyi/ /
de bzhin gshegs pa sgra ma yin/ / sgra ni ma gtogs gzhan du yang / / sangs rgyas shes par mi rung ngo/ / ji ltar bdag gis mthong tshul du/ /
'di ni shes bya'i gnas ma yin/ / sangs rgyas byang chub blang du med/ / de la rnam par rtog pa med/ / sangs rgyas chos rnams gang dag kyang / /
su la'ang sangs rgyas gsungs pa med/ / sems can bsam pa ji bzhin du/ / de la de 'dra ston pa mdzad/ /

The grasped cannot be grasped, The seen cannot be seen, The heard cannot be heard: The one mind is inconceivable.
The finite and the infinite Are both ungraspable; If any want to apprehend them, Ultimately they apprehend nothing.
To say what should not be said Is self-deception; When one’s own task is not complete, One cannot gladden others.
Those who wish to laud the Buddha’s Boundless body of wondrous form Could not express it fully Even in countless eons.
Just as the wish-fulfilling jewel Can manifest all colors, Being colorless yet manifesting color, So are all the Buddhas.
Also like clear space Is formless and invisible And though it shows all forms None can see space,
So it is with the Buddhas; They manifest infinite forms everywhere Yet are not in the province of mental activity So no one is able to see them.
Though the Buddha’s voice is heard, The sound is not the Buddha; And yet not apart from sound Can the Truly Awake be known.
Enlightenment has no coming or going; It’s apart from all discriminations: How then can one Say he is able to see it?
The Buddhas have no doctrine: How could Buddha have any explanation? It is just in accord with one’s own mind One thinks Buddha expounds such a doctrine.
shin tu rgyas pa chen po'i mdo/ sangs rgyas phal po che zhes bya ba las/ rab mtshe ma'i gnas su byang chub sems dpa' 'dus pas tshigs su bcad pa bstan pa'i le'u zhes bya ba ste/ nyi shu lnga pa'o// //

de nas de'i tshe byang chub sems dpa' yon tan dang ldan pas sangs rgyas kyi mthus byang chub sems dpa'i ting nge 'dzin shin tu rnam par phye ba'i rnam par 'byed pa zhes bya ba la mnyam par bzhag par gyur to/ / de ltar byang chub sems dpa' yon tan dang ldan pa byang chub sems dpa'i ting nge 'dzin rnam par phye ba'i rnam par 'byed pa de la mnyam par bzhag ma thag tu de'i tshe phyogs bcu re rer yang 'jig rten gyi khams sangs rgyas kyi zhing stong phrag bcu'i rdul shin tu phra ba snyed 'das pa'i pha rol nas de bzhin gshegs pa'i mtshan yon tan dang ldan pa zhes bya ba sangs rgyas kyi zhing stong phrag bcu'i rdul shin tu phra ba snyed kyis zhal bstan pa mthong ste/ sangs rgyas bcom ldan 'das de dag gis de la 'di skad ces bka' stsal to/ / yon tan dang ldan pa/ de ltar khyod byang chub sems dpa'i ting nge 'dzin shin tu rnam par phye ba'i rnam par 'byed pa la mnyam par bzhag pa legs so/ / legs so/ / rigs kyi bu/ khyod la ni; de bzhin gshegs pa sangs rgyas kyi zhing stong phrag bcu'i rdul shin tu phra ba snyed thams cad kyang mtshan mthun pa sha stag gis 'di ltar bcom ldan 'das de bzhin gshegs pa rnam par snang mdzad kyi sngon gyi smon lam dang / sngon gyi byin gyi rlabs dang / byang chub sems dpa' rnams kyi dge ba'i rtsa bas shin tu brtan pas na/ 'di ltar chos bstan pa dang / sangs rgyas kyi ye shes rnam par 'phel bar bya ba dang / 'jig rten gyi khams la 'jug par bya ba dang / sems can gyi khams rnam par sgom pa dang / chags pa med pa la 'jug par bya ba dang / sgrib pa med pa'i spyod yul dang / kun nas rab tu sbyor ba dang / thams cad mkhyen pa rab tu sgrub pa dang / chos thams cad khong du chud par bya ba dang / dbang po thams cad yongs su shes par bya ba dang / chos bstan pa thams cad yongs su gzung bar bya ba dang / 'di ltar byang chub sems dpa'i spyod pa bcu brtsam pa rab tu thob par bya ba'i phyir byin gyis brlab pa mdzad kyi/ rigs kyi bu/ khyod kyis sangs rgyas kyi mthu dang / sangs rgyas kyi byin gyi rlabs kyis chos 'di bstan pa la slob par gyis shig/

THEN THE ENLIGHTENING BEING Forest of Virtues, imbued with the Buddha’s power, entered into absorption in the skillful meditation of enlightening beings; when he had entered this absorption, there appeared before him Buddhas from beyond as many lands as atoms in ten thousand buddha-lands from each direction, and all were named Forest of Virtues. They said to the enlightening being Forest of Virtues, “Very good it is, O Child of Buddha, that you are able to enter this concentration in skillful meditation. Good man, it is the collective empowerment of the Buddhas of the same name, as many as atoms in ten thousand buddha-lands from each of the ten directions, and also the power of the past vows and the spiritual force of Vairocana Buddha, as well as the power of the virtues of the enlightening beings, that enables you to enter this concentration and expound the teaching, for the sake of increasing in enlightened knowledge, deep entry into the realm of reality, comprehension of the realms of sentient beings, nonobstruction in what is entered into, nonhindrance in the realm of activity, attainment of infinite skill in means, embracing of the essence of all knowledge, conscious realization of all truths, knowledge of all faculties, and ability to uphold and explain all the teachings; in other words, it is for initiating ten kinds of practice of enlightening beings. Good man, you should receive the spiritual power of the Buddhas to expound this teaching.”

de nas sangs rgyas bcom ldan 'das de dag gis byang chub sems dpa' yon tan dang ldan pa la chags pa med pa nyid nye bar sgrub pa mdzad do/ / bsgribs pa med pa nyid nye bar sgrub pa mdzad do/ / byin gyi rlabs nyid nye bar sgrub pa mdzad do/ / slob dpon med pa nyid nye bar sgrub pa mdzad do/ / rmongs pa med pa nyid nye bar sgrub pa mdzad do/ / tha dad pa med pa nyid nye bar sgrub pa mdzad do/ / kha na ma tho ba med pa nyid nye bar sgrub pa mdzad do/ / tshad med pa nyid nye bar sgrub pa mdzad do/ / zil gyis mi non pa nyid nye bar sgrub pa mdzad do/ / zhum pa med pa nyid nye bar sgrub pa mdzad do/ / de ci'i phyir zhe na/ ting nge 'dzin 'di nyid kyi chos nyid thob pa'i phyir ro/ /

Then the Buddhas bestowed on the enlightening being Forest of Virtues unobstructed knowledge, unattached knowledge, uninterrupted knowledge, teacherless knowledge, knowledge without folly, unvarying knowledge, unerring knowledge, immeasurable knowledge, invincible knowledge, unflagging knowledge, and knowledge that cannot be taken away. Why? Because the power of this concentration is naturally thus.

de nas sangs rgyas bcom ldan 'das de dag gis phyag g.yas pa brkyang ste byang chub sems dpa' yon tan dang ldan pa'i mgo la byug pa mdzad do/ / sangs rgyas bcom ldan 'das de dag gis de ltar reg ma thag tu byang chub sems dpa' yon tan dang ldan pa ting nge 'dzin de las langs te byang chub sems dpa' rnams la smras pa; kye rgyal ba'i sras dag / byang chub sems dpa'i las ni/ bsam gyis mi khyab ste/ de ni/ 'di ltar chos kyi dbyings kyis klas so/ / nam mkha'i dbyings kyi mthar thug go /kye rgyal ba'i sras dag / de ci'i phyir zhe na/ de ni/ 'di ltar byang chub sems dpa' sems dpa' chen po rnams ni/ 'das pa'i sangs rgyas bcom ldan 'das rnams kyi spyod pa la'ang slob bo/ / ma byon pa'i sangs rgyas bcom ldan 'das rnams kyi spyod pa la'ang slob bo/ / da ltar byung ba'i sangs rgyas bcom ldan 'das rnams kyi spyod pa la'ang slob bo/ / kye rgyal ba'i sras dag / byang chub sems dpa' rnams kyi spyod pa gang la bsam ste de skad du smras pa de dag gang zhe na/ kye rgyal ba'i sras dag / bcu po 'di dag ni/ byang chub sems dpa' rnams kyi spyod pa sangs rgyas bcom ldan 'das 'das pa dang / ma byon pa dang / da ltar byung ba rnams kyis gsungs pa dang / gsung ba dang / gsung bar 'gyur ba ste/ bcu gang zhe na/ 'di lta ste/ dga' bar byed pa zhes bya ba byang chub sems dpa' spyod pa dang po dang / bde ba skyed pa zhes bya ba byang chub sems dpa'i spyod pa gnyis pa dang / mi mthun pa med pa zhes bya ba byang chub sems dpa'i spyod pa gsum pa dang / mi zad pa zhes bya ba byang chub sems dpa'i spyod pa bzhi pa dang / rmongs pa med pa zhes bya ba byang chub sems dpa'i spyod pa lnga pa dang / lta ba bzang po zhes bya ba byang chub sems dpa'i spyod pa drug pa dang / gnas med pa zhes bya ba byang chub sems dpa'i spyod pa bdun pa dang / thub par dka' ba zhes bya ba byang chub sems dpa'i spyod pa brgyad pa dang / chos bzang po zhes bya ba byang chub sems dpa'i spyod pa dgu pa dang / bden pa dang ldan pa zhes bya ba byang chub sems dpa'i spyod pa bcu pa dag ste/ kye rgyal ba'i sras dag / bcu po de dag ni/ byang chub sems dpa' rnams kyi spyod pa sangs rgyas bcom ldan 'das 'das pa dang / ma byon pa dang / da ltar byung ba rnams kyis gsungs pa dang / gsung ba dang / gsung bar 'gyur ba'o/ /

Then the Buddhas each extended their right hands and patted the enlightening being Forest of Virtues on the head, whereupon he rose from concentration and addressed the enlightening beings, saying, “O Buddha Children, the practice of enlightening beings is inconceivable, equal to the space of the cosmos. Why? Because enlightening beings cultivate practice in emulation of the Buddhas of past, present, and future. Buddha-Children, great enlightening beings have ten kinds of practices, which are expounded by the Buddhas of past, present, and future. What are the ten? (1) The practice of giving joy; (2) beneficial practice; (3) the practice of nonopposition; (4) the practice of indomitability; (5) the practice of nonconfusion; (6) the practice of good manifestation; (7) the practice of nonattachment; (8) the practice of that which is difficult to attain; (9) the practice of good teachings; (10) the practice of truth.

kye rgyal ba'i sras dag / de la byang chub sems dpa'i spyod pa dang po dga' bar byed pa zhes bya ba gang zhe na/ kye rgyal ba'i sras dag / 'di la byang chub sems dpa' sems dpa' chen po sangs rgyas bcom ldan 'das rnams kyi sngon gyi spyod pa'i rjes su slob cing / rjes su dran par bya ba dang / yid zhum pa med pa dang / yid dang bas kun tu 'phel bar bya ba dang / yongs su bzung ba dang / yang dag par bstan pa dang / rjes su rgya che bar byed cing / sdug bsngal ba'i sems can bde bar bya ba'i phyir sems can thams cad la bdog pa thams cad yongs su gtong ba dang / 'gyod pa med pa'i sems kyi sbyor ba dang / rnam par smin pa la ye rngam pa med pa dang / grags pa 'dod pa med pa dang / gnyen 'dod pa med pa dang / khe 'dod pa med pa dang / gzhan rjes su srung ba dang / pha rol la phan gdags pa dang / sems can thams cad la phan gdags pa'i sems kyis sbyin pa'i bdag po sbyin pa byed pa yin te/ kye rgyal ba'i sras dag / 'di ni/ byang chub sems dpa'i spyod pa dang po'o/ /

“What is the great enlightening being’s practice of giving joy? Here the enlightening beings are magnanimous givers, bestowing whatever they have with an equanimous mind, without regret, without hoping for reward, without seeking honor, without coveting material benefits, but only to rescue and safeguard all living beings, to include all living beings in their care, to benefit all living beings, and to emulate the original practice of all Buddhas, recall the original practice of all Buddhas, delight in the original practice of all Buddhas, purify the original practice of all Buddhas, further develop the original practice of all Buddhas, make manifest the original practice of all Buddhas, and expound the original practice of all Buddhas, to cause all sentient beings to be relieved of pain and suffering and attain comfort and happiness.

spyod pa de la gnas pa'i byang chub sems dpa' ni/ skye bo mang po'i yid du 'ong ba yin te/ de ni/ sems can dbul po gang dang gang na yod pa de dang der smon lam gyi dbang gis rab tu skyes te/ skyes nas kyang zad mi shes pa'i longs spyod dang ldan zhing shin tu phyug pa yin te/ de la gal te dus gcig tu slong ba'i srog chags bye ba khrag khrig brgya stong grangs med pa zhig 'ongs te/ 'di skad du/ kye shes par gyis shig / bdag cag thams cad ni/ bkres pas 'chi'o/ / gal te bdag cag gis khyod kyi sha zos na ni/ 'tsho bar 'gyur ro/ / zhes tshig tu smra bar gyur kyang byang chub sems dpa' ni/ sbyin bdag nyid kyang sems can gyi bsam pa yongs su rdzogs par ma byas kyi bar du

“When great enlightening beings cultivate this practice, they cause all living beings joy and delight. In any place there is poverty and want, they go there by the power of will to be born noble and wealthy, so that even if every single moment countless beings come to the enlightening beings and say, ‘O benevolent one, we are poor and in need, without sustenance, hungry and weak, worn out and miserable, on the brink of death; please pity us and give us your flesh to eat so that we may live,’ the enlightening beings would immediately give it to them, to gladden and satisfy them. Even should countless hundreds of thousands of beings come begging this way, the enlightening beings would not shrink back, but would rather increase even more in kindness and compassion. Indeed, because sentient beings all come seeking, the enlightening beings, seeing them, would become more joyful, and think, ‘I have gained a fine boon; these beings are my field of blessings, they are my good friends and benefactors—without my asking them, they come to cause me to enter into the Buddha’s teaching. I should now cultivate learning in this way, not controverting the wishes of sentient beings.’ They also form this thought: ‘May all the good that I have done, do, and will do, cause me in the future, in all worlds, among all beings, to receive an immense body, so as to satisfy all starving beings with the flesh of this body, and may I not die so long as even a single tiny creature is still not filled, and may the flesh I cut off be inexhaustible. By this virtue may I attain unexcelled complete perfect enlightenment, and experience great nirvana; and may those who eat my flesh also attain perfect enlightenment, attain impartial knowledge, fulfill all Buddha teachings, extensively perform Buddha work until entering extinction without remainder. If the heart of even one sentient being is unfulfilled, I will not attain unexcelled perfect enlightenment.’

bdag tu 'du shes pa'am/ sems can du 'du shes pa'am/ srid par 'du shes pa'am/ srog tu 'du shes pa'am/ so so'i skye bor 'du shes pa'am/ gang zag tu 'du shes pa'am/ shed can du 'du shes pa'am/ shed bdag tu 'du shes pa'am/ byed pa por 'du shes pa'am/ tshor ba por 'du shes pa'am/ gzhan du chos kyi dbyings nye bar gzung ba dang / sems can gyi khams mtha' yas pa'i chos nyid nye bar gzung ba dang / stong pa'i chos nyid nye bar gzung ba dang / 'dod chags dang bral ba'i chos nyid nye bar gzung ba dang / mtshan nyid med pa'i chos nyid nye bar gzung ba dang / dngos po med pa'i chos nyid nye bar gzung ba dang / gnas med pa'i chos nyid nye bar gzung ba dang / gzhi med pa'i chos nyid nye bar gzung ba dang / mngon par 'du bya ba med pa'i chos nyid nye bar gzung ba ma gtogs par mngon par 'tshang rgya bar ma gyur cig / ces te/

“Thus do enlightening beings benefit the living, yet without any concept of self or any concept of sentient beings, or any concept of existence, or any concept of life, without various concepts — no concept of personality, no concept of person, no concept of human being, no concept of doer or receiver — they only observe the infinity of the realm of reality and the realm of sentient beings, their emptiness, absence of existents, signlessness, insubstantiality, indeterminacy, nondependence, and noncreation.

de ni/ bdag kyang yang dag par rjes su mi mthong / bdag gi lus kyang yang dag par rjes su mi mthong / len to/ / zhes bya bar yang yang dag par rjes su mi mthong / len pa yang yang dag par rjes su mi mthong / sbyin pa'i gnas kyang yang dag par rjes su ma mthong ste/ de ni/ las kyang yang dag par rjes su mi mthong / rnam par smin pa yang yang dag par rjes su mi mthong / 'bras bu'ang yang dag par rjes su mi mthong / 'bras bu chen po'ang yang dag par rjes su mi mthong / 'bras bu chung ngu yang yang dag par rjes su mi mthong /

“When they perform this contemplation, they do not see themselves, they do not see anything given, they do not see a receiver, they do not see a field of blessings, they do not see a deed, they do not see any reward, they do not see any result, they do not see a great result, they do not see a small result.

de 'das pa'i dus kyi sems can thams cad kyi lus zhig par yid la byed do/ / ma 'ongs pa dang / da ltar byung ba'i sems can thams cad kyi lus 'jig par yid la byed do/ / de 'di snyam du sems te/ kye ma/ sems can 'di dag rang gi lus grangs med pa zhig ni/ 'gags te/ 'gag cing 'gag par 'gyur yang snying po med pa'i lus las snying po mi len pa ni/ ngo mtshar che'o/ / de lta yin gyi/ bdag gis sems can thams cad bde bas rim gro bya ba'i phyir de bzhin gshegs pa'i rjes su bslab par bya'o/ / thams cad mkhyen pa'i ye shes kyang mngon par sangs rgyas te chos thams cad rnam par sbyang ba'i phyir chos nyid mi 'jig pa nye bar bzung ste/ dus gsum mnyam pa nyid du mthun pa'i tshul gyis zhi bar bya bas sems can rnams la chos bstan par bya'o/ / snyam du sems te/ kye rgyal ba'i sras dag /

“Then the enlightening beings observe that all the bodies taken on by living beings in the past, future, and present eventually perish; then they form this thought: ‘How remarkable it is how foolish and ignorant sentient beings are; within birth and death they receive countless bodies, which are perishable and transient, soon returning to decay and extinction: having already passed away, now passing away, and yet to pass away, they still cannot use the destructible body to seek the indestructible body. I should learn all that the Buddhas learn, to realize omniscience, know all truths, and explain to sentient beings the indestructible nature of reality, which is equal in past, present, and future, and which accords with utmost tranquility and serenity, to cause them to permanently attain peace and happiness.’
'di ni/ byang chub sems dpa'i spyod pa dang po ste/ dga' bar byed pa zhes bya'o/ /
“This is called the great enlightening beings’ first practice, of giving joy.

kye rgyal ba'i sras dag / byang chub sems dpa' rnams kyi spyod pa gnyis pa bde ba skyed pa zhes bya ba de gang zhe na/ kye rgyal ba'i sras dag / 'di la byang chub sems dpa' tshul khrims dang ldan pa yin te/ de ni/ mi gnas pa yin/ gzugs dang / sgra dang / dri dang / ro dang / reg la mi gnas pa ston pa yin/ rigs kyi bu bdag nyid che ba la mi gnas pa yin/ rgyud kyi bdag nyid che ba la mi gnas pa yin/ zas kyi bdag nyid che ba la mi gnas pa yin/ gzugs kyi bdag nyid che ba la mi gnas pa yin/ longs spyod kyi bdag nyid che ba la mi gnas pa yin te/ de ltar de ni/ tshul khrims las yongs su nyams pa med cing / 'di ltar kun nas 'khor ba med pa dang / kun tu btsal ba med pa dang / yongs su gdung ba med pa dang / bar chad med pa dang / gtse ba med pa dang / 'khrul pa med par bya'o/ / snad pa med par bya'o/ / sangs rgyas kyis bsngags pa'i chos rnams yongs su gzung ngo/ / snyam du sems te/

“What is the great enlightening beings’ beneficial practice? Here enlightening beings maintain pure self-control, and their minds have no attachment to color or form, sound, fragrance, flavor, or feeling. Also they preach this to sentient beings. They do not seek power, social status, wealth, appearance, or dominions. They have no attachment to anything, but just firmly uphold pure conduct, thinking, ‘As I maintain pure discipline, I shall surely get rid of all bondage, the torment of craving, oppression, slander, and disturbance, and will attain the impartial truth praised by the Buddhas.’

kye rgyal ba'i sras dag / byang chub sems dpa' de lta bu'i tshul khrims dang ldan pa'i drung du gal te nyin gcig tu bdud bye ba khrag khrig brgya stong zhig 'ongs te/ bdud re re zhing yang lha'i bu mo bye ba khrag khrig brgya stong 'dod pa'i cho ga thams cad la mkhas pa/ bde bar rim gror bya ba thams cad thogs pa/ lus kyi rgyan gyis lus yongs su rgyas pa bye ba khrag khrig brgya stong re re bsnyen kyang byang chub sems dpas 'dod pa ni/ bla na med pa yang dag par rdzogs pa'i byang chub la bar du gcod pa yin par shes nas ston pa mngon du gyur pa'i phyir 'dod pa dang ldan pa'i sems bskyed pa gcig kyang mi 'byung ste/ byang chub sems dpa' ni/ thams cad mkhyen pa nyid yid la bya ba dang mi 'bral lo/ /

“When enlightening beings maintain pure discipline in this way, even if countless devils should come to them in a single day, each bringing countless goddesses all well versed in the arts of pleasure, beautiful and alluring, with various amusing things, in order to disturb the enlightening beings’ attention on the Way, the enlightening beings think, ‘These desires are hindrances to the Way and obstruct unexcelled enlightenment.’ Therefore they do not conceive even a single thought of lust; their minds are as pure as Buddha. The only exception is in terms of expedient means to teach and transform sentient beings—yet they still do not relinquish the determination for omniscience.
'dod pa'i don du sems can 'ga' la'ang sdug bsngal gyi rgyur 'gyur ba mi byed de/ chung ngu na srog gi dbang po 'gags par gyur kyang gzhan la mi dga' ba mi skyed do/ /
“Enlightening beings do not afflict a single sentient being in pursuit of their own desires; they would rather die themselves than to do anything which would afflict a single being.

kye rgyal ba'i sras dag / byang chub sems dpa' rnams ni/ de bzhin gshegs pa mthong nas chung ngu na sems kyi rgyud gcig tsam gyis kyang 'dod pa la mi spyod na/ gnyis kyis gnyis sbyar ba lta smos kyang ci dgos te/ 'di ni/ gnas med do/ /
“After enlightening beings have gotten to see the Buddha, they never arouse a single thought of desire, much less act upon desire.

byang chub sems dpa' ni/ 'di ltar sems skyes te/ sems can 'di dag ni/ yun ring po nas de ltar gzhol ba/ de ltar 'bab pa; de ltar bab pa/ de ltar mos pa/ de lta bu'i spyod yul can/ de ltar nges pa/ de ltar bying ba/ de ltar non pa/ de ltar chags pa/ de ltar zhugs pa yin gyi/ bdag gis ni; bdud 'di dag dang / bdud kyi bu mo 'di dag dang / sems can thams cad ci nas kyang bla na med pa'i tshul khrims yongs su dag pa la bkod de/ thams cad mkhyen pa nyid la phyir mi ldog par byas nas bla na med pa yang dag par rdzogs pa'i byang chub tu mngon par 'tshang rgya bar byas te/ phung po'i lhag ma ma lus pa'i mya ngan las 'das pa'i dbyings su yongs su mya ngan las 'da' bar 'gyur ba de ltar bya'o/ / de ci'i phyir zhe na/ 'di ltar sangs rgyas thams cad kyi rjes su bslab ste mi bya ba thams cad yongs su spangs pa dang / lus kyis mi shes pa thams cad yongs su spangs pa ma yin pa dang / sems kyis kyang ma yin pa de ni/ bdag cag gi las yin gyi/ kye rgyal ba'i sras dag / bdag cag gis sangs rgyas kyi chos thams cad kyi rjes su song ba'i ye shes kyis sems can thams cad kyi phyin ci log rab tu spang ba'i phyir chos bstan par bya'o; ; phyin ci log ni/ sems can rnams las gzhan na'ang med de/ phyin ci log rnams las kyang sems can rnams gud na med do/ / phyin ci log tu'ang sems can 'dus pa ma yin/ sems can du'ang phyin ci log 'dus pa ma yin no/ / phyin ci log rnams kyang sems can ma yin/ sems can rnams kyang phyin ci log ma yin no/ / phyin ci log rnams ni/ nang na'ang med/ phyin ci log rnams ni/ phyi rol na'ang med do/ / sems can rnams kyang nang na yang med/ sems can rnams ni/ phyi rol na yang med de/ chos de dag thams cad ni/ gsog / gsob/ rdzun pa/ bslu ba'i chos can te/ sgyu ma lta bu byis pa slu ba dang / ngan pa/ chung ba/ snying po med pa/ rmi lam lta bu/ mig yor lta bu ste; de dag khong du chud par bya ba'i phyir 'du byed rjes su rtogs pa'o/ / 'du byed rjes su rtogs pa'i phyir mya ngan las 'das pa ste/ de ni/ sangs rgyas kyi byang chub tu rnam par 'tshang rgya bar byed de/ rgal bas ni/ sgrol bar byed/ grol bas ni/ 'grol bar byed/ zhi bas ni/ zhi bar byed/ dbugs phyin pas ni/ dbugs 'byin par byed/ bkrus pas ni; 'khru bar byed/ dag pas ni/ dag par byed/ mya ngan las 'das pas ni/ mya ngan las 'da' bar byed/ bde bar gyur pas ni/ bde bar byed pa ste/

“At this point, enlightening beings think, ‘All sentient beings, throughout the long night of ignorance, think of desires, pursue desires, and are attached to desires; their minds are set in their ways and they are addicted to desires, whirling along with them, not having any freedom. I should cause these devils and these goddesses, and all sentient beings, to abide by the unexcelled precepts; once they abide in pure discipline, their minds will never turn back from the direction of universal knowledge, and eventually they will attain unexcelled complete perfect enlightenment, and finally enter complete extinction with no remainder. Why? This is the work we ought to do. We should follow the Buddhas in cultivating this learning, and having done so, divorce all bad actions and get rid of the ignorance of the idea of self, enter all Buddha-teachings by means of knowledge, and explain them to sentient beings, to rid them of delusion, all the while knowing, however, that there is no delusion apart from sentient beings and there are no sentient beings apart from delusion, that there are no sentient beings within delusion and no delusion within sentient beings, and also that it is not that delusion is sentient beings or that sentient beings are a delusion—delusion is not something inside or outside, and sentient beings are not something inside or outside. They know all things are unreal, suddenly arising and suddenly perishing, having no solidity or stability, like dreams, like reflections, like phantoms, like illusions, fooling the ignorant. Those who understand in this way will be able to comprehend all actions, to master birth and death as well as nirvana, to realize enlightenment, to save themselves and cause others to gain salvation, to liberate themselves and enable others to gain liberation, to conquer themselves and cause others to be tamed, to become tranquil themselves and enable others to become tranquil, to be secure themselves and enable others to be secure, to be free from defilement themselves and cause others to be free from defilement, to be pure themselves and cause others to be pure, to be dispassionate themselves and cause others to be dispassionate, to be happy themselves and cause others to be happy.

bdag cag gis ni; de bzhin gshegs pa dang skal pa mi mthun par gnas par mi bya ste/ bdag cag gis ni/ 'jig rten gyi spyod pa thams cad spang bar bya'o/ / bdag cag gis ni/ sangs rgyas kyi chos thams cad dang ldan par bya'o/ / bdag cag gis ni/ bla na med pa'i chos mnyam pa nyid kyis gnas par bya'o/ / bdag cag gis ni/ sems can thams cad la sems mnyam pas yang dag par 'jug par bya'o/ / bdag cag gis ni/ yul thams cad yongs su shes pa dang ldan par bya'o; ; bdag cag gis ni/ yongs su spyod pa kha na ma tho ba med pa'i bag chags dang ldan par bya'o/ / bdag cag gis ni/ rtogs pa thams cad dang ldan par bya'o; ; bdag cag gis ni/ 'byung ba thams cad la mkhas pa dang ldan par bya'o/ / bdag cag gis ni/ bla na med pa'i ye shes kun tu mtha' yas pa/ brjod du med pa; mi gnas pa/ 'phos pa med pa/ mtha' dang dbus med pa/ mi zad pa/ gzugs med pa/ bstan du med pa la rab tu mos par bya'o/ / zhes zer te/

“Here enlightening beings also form this thought: ‘I should follow all the enlightened ones, detach from all worldly actions, fulfill all qualities of buddhahood, abide in supreme equanimity, be impartial toward all beings, clearly understand the objective realm, get rid of all error, cut off all conceptualizations, abandon all attachments, and skillfully engineer emancipation, to ever abide mentally in unexcelled, inexplicable, independent, immutable, measureless, boundless, inexhaustible, formless, most profound wisdom.’
kye rgyal ba'i sras dag/ 'di ni/ byang chub sems dpa'i spyod pa gnyis pa ste/ bde ba skyed pa zhes bya'o/ /
“This is called the great enlightening beings’ second practice, of beneficial action.

kye rgyal ba'i sras dag / de la byang chub sems dpa' sems dpa' chen po rnams kyi byang chub sems dpa'i spyod pa gsum pa mi mthun pa med pa zhes bya ba gang zhe na/ kye rgyal ba'i sras dag / 'di la byang chub sems dpa' chos nyid la brtson te bzod pa dang ldan zhing mngon par smra ba'i ngang tshul can yin te/ de yang bdag la gnod pa ma yin/ pha rol la gnod pa ma yin/ gnyis ka la gnod pa ma yin/ bdag bsdu ba ma yin/ gzhan bsdu ba ma yin/ gnyis ka bsdu ba ma yin/ bdag yongs su gzung ba ma yin/ gzhan yongs su gzung ba ma yin; gnyis ka yongs su gzung ba ma yin/ yang dag par blangs pa grags pa'i phyir ma yin gyi/ byang chub sems dpa' ni/ sems 'di ltar skye ste/ bdag cag gis sems can thams cad la mi dge ba thams cad spang ba'i phyir chos bstan par bya'o/ / 'dod chags spang ba dang / zhe sdang spang ba dang / gti mug spang ba dang / nga rgyal spang ba dang / 'chab pa spang ba dang / phrag dog spang ba dang / ser sna spang ba dang / g.yo dang sgyu spang ba dang / bzod pa dang nges pa la gzhag pa'i phyir bdag cag gis sems can thams cad la chos bstan par bya'o/ / zhes te/

“What is the great enlightening beings’ practice of nonopposition? Here enlightening beings always practice tolerance and forbearance, being humble and respectful, not harming self, others, or both; not stealing or causing others to steal, not being attached to themselves, to others, or to both; not seeking fame or profit. They only think, ‘I should always expound the Teaching to sentient beings, to cause them to divorce all evils, to cut off greed, anger, folly, pride, hypocrisy, stinginess, jealousy, obsequiousness, and dishonesty, and cause them to always abide peacefully in forbearance and harmony.’

kye rgyal ba'i sras dag / byang chub sems dpa' ni/ de lta bur bzod cing nges pa dang ldan pa yin pas/ de la gal te srog chags brgya stong bye ba grangs med pa zhig 'ongs la/ srog chags de dag re re zhing yang kha bye ba khrag khrig brgya stong grangs med par sprul te drung du phyin la/ kha re re nas kyang mi snyan par brjod pa bye ba khrag khrig brgya stong grangs med pas/ mi snyan cing yid du mi 'ong ba dang / mi 'dod pa dang / mi sdug pa dang / mi dga' ba dang / mi tshul ba dang / 'phags pa ma yin pa dang / 'phags pa ma yin pas brjod pa dang / 'phags pa ma yin pas bsnyen pa dang / yongs su spang bar bya ba sha stag tu brjod de/ lag pa re re zhing yang 'thab cha bye ba khrag khrig brgya stong grangs med pa thogs te/ byang chub sems dpa'i lus la gnod par byas la/ nyin gcig tu ji lta ba bzhin du bskal pa grangs med par yang mtshams med cing ngal mi shes/ skyo mi shes/ rgyun mi chad/ gtong ba med/ / sdod pa med/ gcugs su med/ dbugs 'byin pa med/ phyir sri ba med par brtags kyang
kye rgyal ba'i sras dag / de lta bu'i 'jigs pa chen po/ mi zad pa/ ma rungs pa/ skyi g.ya' ba/ sdug bsngal ba/ nyams su 'bab pa/ tsha ba/ rtsub pas phog ste srog la bab par 'chi ma khad kyang de la byang chub sems dpa' 'di snyam du sems te/ sdug bsngal gyi rnam pa 'di tsam dag gis phog pa la gal te bdag gis sems 'khrug pa zhig byas su zin na/ de ni/ ma dul ba dang / mi bden pa dang / mi mkhas pa dang / ma zhi ba dang / ma bsgoms pa dang / ma bsdams pa dang / ma khug pa dang / byas pa med pa dang / mnyam par ma bzhag pa dang / bdag gi lus la brten pas gzhan gyi sems mgu bar bya bar mi nus kyi zhes te/ de lus dang sems kyi rang bzhin shes nas thog ma dang tha ma med par skye ba dang / 'khor ba'i sdug bsngal rjes su dran nas chos 'di dag ni/ tshul gyis de bzhin no/ / zhes nas phyir zhing sems dang bar byed/ rab tu dang bar byed/ dga' bar byed/ rab tu dga' bar byed/ tshim par byed/ gzengs mtho bar byed/ spro bar byed/ rab tu spro bar byed/ 'dul bar byed/ yongs su 'doms par byed de/ de ltar bdag gis kyang sangs rgyas kyi chos la bzhag ste/ sems can thams cad la'ang don 'di bstan par bya'o/ / snyam mo/ / de ci'i phyir zhe na/ 'di ltar lus 'di ni/ bdag dang bdag gis stong pa ste/ rang bzhin gyis stong pa'o/ / stong pa nyid la ni/ bde ba'am/ sdug bsngal pa'am/ gnyis su brjod pa med pa gang yang med do/ / gang stong pa de la ci'ang med de/ chos thams cad ni/ ci'ang ma yin pa yin gyi/ de dag gis kyang yang dag par shes par byas te sems can thams cad la dngos por 'dzin pa spang ba'i phyir chos bstan par bya dgos kyi/ de ltar bdag gis 'di dag la byams pa'i sems dang / phan pa'i sems dang / bde ba'i sems dang / snying rje ba'i sems dang / snying brtse ba'i sems dang / phan par dga' ba'i sems dang / yongs su mi gtong ba'i sems dang / 'tshang rgya ba'i sems dang / byang chub pa'i sems dang / mi 'phrog pa'i sems dang / sangs rgyas kyi tshul gyi rjes su bsnyegs pa'i sems kyis bzod par bya'o/ / snyam mo/ /

“When enlightening beings achieve this forbearance, even if countless beings should come to them and each being should produce countless mouths and utter countless words—unpleasant words, unwholesome words, displeasing words, undesirable words, words which are not those of the benevolent or the virtuous, words which are not those of wisdom, words which are not in accord with sagacity, words which sages do not approach, detestable words, and unbearable words—even if they abuse and revile the enlightening beings with such speech, and, furthermore, if they all had countless hands, bearing countless cudgels, with which they attacked and injured the enlightening beings, without relenting, for immeasurable eons, should enlightening beings encounter such torture, their hair standing on end, their life about to end, they form this thought: ‘If my mind is disturbed by this suffering, then I have not mastered myself, I am not self-possessed, I do not understand myself, I am uncultivated, I am not properly stabilized, I am not at peace, I am careless, I give rise to attachments — how can I enable others to attain purity of mind?’
“Then the enlightening beings also think, ‘Since beginningless time I have dwelt in birth and death and experienced its pains and vexations,’ and thus reflecting, they redouble their efforts, purify their minds, and attain joy. They skillfully tune and concentrate themselves, and, themselves able to abide in the Buddha-teaching, they also enable sentient beings to attain the same condition. They further reflect, ‘This body is empty and null, it has no self or possessions, it has no reality—it is void by nature, with no duality. Neither pain nor pleasure has any existence, because all things are empty. I should expound this teaching for people, to enable all sentient beings to do away with their views. Therefore, though I meet with suffering today, I should accept it with patience, out of compassion for beings, to benefit beings, to pacify beings, out of pity for beings, to take care of beings and not abandon them, to attain enlightenment myself and also to enable others to attain enlightenment, so that my mind will never regress, and so that I may progress on the wav of Buddhahood.’
kye rgyal ba'i sras dag / 'di ni/ byang chub sems dpa' sems dpa' chen po rnams kyi byang chub sems dpa'i spyod pa gsum pa ste/ mi mthun pa med pa zhes bya'o/ /
“This is called the enlightening beings’ third practice, of nonopposition.

kye rgyal ba'i sras dag / byang chub sems dpa' sems dpa' chen po rnams kyi spyod pa bzhi pa mi zad pa zhes bya ba de gang zhe na/ 'di la byang chub sems dpa' sems dpa' chen po brtson 'grus dang ldan pa yin te/ brtson 'grus mchog dang ldan pa yin/ brtson 'grus rab dang ldan pa yin/ brtson 'grus dam pa dang ldan pa yin/ brtson 'grus phul dang ldan pa yin/ brtson 'grus 'phags pa dang ldan pa yin/ brtson 'grus gya nom pa dang ldan pa yin/ brtson 'grus bla na med pa dang ldan pa yin/ brtson 'grus mi nyams pa dang ldan pa yin te/ de la 'dod chags kyi rang bzhin med/ zhe sdang gi rang bzhin med/ gti mug gi rang bzhin med/ nga rgyal gyi rang bzhin med do/ / 'chab pa'i rang bzhin med/ phrag dog gi rang bzhin med/ 'jungs pa'i rang bzhin med/ sgyu'i rang bzhin med/ khrel med pa'i rang bzhin med do; ; de ni/ sems can gang la yang mtho ba tsam pa'i phyir brtson 'grus mi rtsom ste/ gzhan du na nyon mongs pa thams cad yongs su spang ba'i phyir brtson 'grus rtsom mo/ / bag la nyal ba thams cad yang dag par gzhom pa'i phyir brtson 'grus rtsom mo/ / bag chags thams cad yongs su bsal ba'i phyir brtson 'grus rtsom mo/ / sems can gyi khams yongs su shes par bya ba'i phyir brtson 'grus rtsom mo/ / 'chi 'pho dang / skye ba thams cad yongs su shes par bya ba'i phyir brtson 'grus rtsom mo/ / nyon mongs pa thams cad yongs su shes par bya ba'i phyir brtson 'grus rtsom mo/ / sems can gyi bsam pa thams cad yongs su shes par bya ba'i phyir brtson 'grus rtsom mo/ / sems can thams cad kyi spyod yul yongs su shes par bya ba'i phyir brtson 'grus rtsom mo/ / sems can thams cad kyi dbang po dang brtson 'grus rnam pa tha dad pa mchog dang tha ma'i rgyu yongs su shes par bya ba'i phyir brtson 'grus rtsom mo/ / sems can thams cad kyi sems dang / spyod pa shes par bya ba'i phyir brtson 'grus rtsom mo/ / chos kyi dbyings thams cad la 'jug pa yongs su shes par bya ba'i phyir brtson 'grus rtsom mo/ / sangs rgyas kyi chos thams cad kyi rang bzhin dang / ngo bo nyid yongs su shes par bya ba'i phyir brtson 'grus rtsom mo/ / sangs rgyas kyi chos thams cad mnyam pa nyid yongs su shes par bya ba'i phyir brtson 'grus rtsom mo/ / dus gsum la mkhas pa mnyam pa nyid yongs su shes par bya ba'i phyir brtson 'grus rtsom mo/ / sangs rgyas kyi chos thams cad shes pa'i snang ba mnyam pa nyid yongs su shes par bya ba'i phyir brtson 'grus rtsom mo/ / sangs rgyas kyi chos thams cad rtogs par 'gyur ba'i ye shes yongs su shes par bya ba'i phyir brtson 'grus rtsom mo/ / sangs rgyas kyi chos thams cad tshul gcig tu mngon par 'tshang rgya ba yongs su shes par bya ba'i phyir brtson 'grus rtsom mo/ /
