BOOK TWENTY-TWO. Ten Inexhaustible Treasuries

de nas byang chub sems dpa' yon tan dang ldan pas yang byang chub sems dpa' de dag la smras pa/ kye rgyal ba'i sras dag / bcu po 'di dag ni/ byang chub sems dpa' rnams kyi gter yin te/ sangs rgyas bcom ldan 'das 'das pa dang / ma byon pa dang / da ltar byung ba rnams kyis gsungs so/ / gsung ngo/ / gsung bar 'gyur ro/ / bcu gang zhe na/ 'di lta ste/ dad pa'i gter dang / tshul khrims kyi gter dang / ngo tsha shes pa'i gter dang / khrel yod pa'i gter dang / thos pa'i gter dang / gtong ba'i gter dang / dam 'cha' ba'i gter dang / rtogs pa'i gter dang / blo gros kyi gter dang / blo'i gter te; kye rgyal ba'i sras dag / byang chub sems dpa' rnams kyi byang chub sems dpa'i gter bcu po de dag ni/ 'das pa dang / ma byon pa dang / da ltar byung ba'i sangs rgyas bcom ldan 'das rnams kyis gsungs so/ / gsung ngo/ / gsung bar 'gyur ro/ /

THEN THE ENLIGHTENING BEING Forest of Virtues also said to the enlightening beings, “Children of Buddhas, great enlightening beings have ten kinds of treasury, which have been, will be, and are explained by the Buddhas of past, future, and present. What are the ten? They are the treasury of faith, the treasury of ethics, the treasury of shame, the treasury of conscience, the treasury of learning, the treasury of giving, the treasury of wisdom, the treasury of recollection, the treasury of preservation, and the treasury of elocution.

kye rgyal ba'i sras dag / de la dad pa'i gter gang zhe na/ kye rgyal ba'i sras dag / 'di la byang chub sems dpa' chos thams cad stong pa zhes bya bar dad par byed do/ / chos thams cad mtshan ma med pa zhes bya bar dad par byed do/ / chos thams cad smon pa med pa zhes bya bar dad par byed do/ / chos thams cad ma byas pa zhes bya bar dad par byed do/ / chos thams cad ma brtags pa zhes bya bar dad par byed do/ / chos thams cad gnas med pa zhes bya bar dad par byed do/ / chos thams cad tshad med pa zhes bya bar dad par byed do/ / chos thams cad bla na med pa zhes bya bar dad par byed do/ / chos thams cad 'dar mi rung ba zhes bya bar dad par byed do/ / chos thams cad 'byung ba med pa zhes bya bar dad par byed do/ /

“What is the great enlightening being’s treasury of faith? The enlightening beings believe all things are empty, they believe all things are signless, they believe all things are wishless, they believe all things are noncreative, they believe all things are without discrimination, they believe all things have no basis, they believe all things cannot be measured, they believe all things have nothing beyond, they believe all things are hard to transcend, they believe all things are uncreated.

de ni/ chos dang mthun pa'i dad pa dang ldan pa yin te/ chos thams cad bsam gyis mi khyab bo/ / zhes bya bas zhum par mi 'gyur ro/ / sangs rgyas thams cad bsam gyis mi khyab bo/ / zhes bya bas zhum par mi 'gyur ro; ; sems can gyi khams thams cad bsam gyis mi khyab bo/ / zhes bya bas zhum par mi 'gyur ro/ / chos kyi dbyings bsam gyis mi khyab bo/ / zhes bya bas zhum par mi 'gyur ro/ / nam mkha'i dbyings bsam gyis mi khyab bo/ / zhes bya bas zham par mi 'gyur ro/ / mya ngan las 'da' ba'i dbyings bsam gyis mi khyab bo/ / zhes bya bas zhum par mi 'gyur ro/ / 'das pa'i dus bsam gyis mi khyab bo/ / zhes bya bas zhum par mi 'gyur ro/ / ma 'ongs pa'i dus bsam gyis mi khyab bo/ / zhes bya bas zhum par mi 'gyur ro; ; de ltar byung ba'i dus bsam gyis mi khyab bo/ / zhes bya bas zhum par mi 'gyur ro/ / bskal ba thams cad la 'jug pa bsam gyis mi khyab po/ / zhes bya bas zhum par mi 'gyur ro/ /

“If enlightening beings are able in this way to engender pure faith in accord with all things, when they hear all Buddha teachings are inconceivable, their minds are not intimidated; when they hear all Buddhas are inconceivable, their minds are not intimidated; when they hear the realms of sentient beings are inconceivable, their minds are not intimidated; when they hear the realm of reality is inconceivable, their minds are not intimidated; when they hear the realm of space is inconceivable, their minds are not intimidated; when they hear the realm of nirvana is inconceivable, they are not intimidated; when they hear the past, present, and future times are inconceivable, their minds are not intimidated; when they hear entry into all eons is inconceivable, their minds are not intimidated.

de ci'i phyir zhe na/ de'i dad pa ni/ sangs rgyas bcom ldan 'das rnams kyis ji ltar mkhyen pa bzhin du gcig tu nges par gyur ba yin te/ sangs rgyas kyi ye shes kyi mtha' yang zad mi shes so/ / 'jig rten gyi khams rnams kyang zad mi shes te/ 'jig rten gyi khams re rer yang mtha' yas pa'i sangs rgyas bcom ldan 'das rnams bla na med pa yang dag par rdzogs ba'i byang chub tu mngon par sangs rgyas so/ / mngon par 'tshang rgya'o/ / mngon par 'tshang rgya bar 'gyur ro/ / yang dag par byung ngo/ / yang dag par 'byung ngo/ / yang dag par 'byung bar 'gyur ro/ / yongs su mya ngan 'das so/ / yongs su mya ngan las 'da'o/ / yongs su mya ngan las 'da' bar 'gyur te/ sangs rgyas kyi ye shes de ni/ 'bri ba'am/ 'phel ba'am/ skye ba'am/ 'gag pa'am/ 'pho ba'am/ 'gro ba'am/ nye bar byed pa'am/ ring bar byed pa'am/ shes par byed pa'am/ 'byin par byed pa ma yin te/ de ni/ sangs rgyas kyi ye shes la yang dag par gnas pas/ zad pa med cing mtha' yas pa'i dad pa'i gter dang ldan pa yin no/ /

“Why? The enlightening beings have wholehearted, firm faith in the Buddhas; they know the knowledge and wisdom of the Buddhas are boundless and inexhuastible. In each of the countless worlds in the ten directions are innumerable Buddhas who have attained, will attain, or now are attaining unexcelled complete perfect enlightenment, who have appeared, now are appearing, or will appear in the world, who have entered, are now entering, or will enter nirvana—the knowledge and wisdom of those Buddhas neither increase nor decrease, are unborn and imperishable, neither advance nor regress, are not near or far, have neither concern nor indifference. The enlightening beings enter into the Buddhas’ knowledge and wisdom and develop boundless, inexhaustible faith.

kye rgyal ba'i sras dag/ dad pa 'di ni/ mtha' yas pa/ kun tu mtha' yas pa/ mi zad pa/ phyir mi ldog pa/ myu gur gyur ba ma yin pa/ tha dad pa ma yin pa/ ma 'dres pa/ rtsa ba brtan pa/ 'phags pa dang mthun pa/ de bzhin gshegs pa rigs kyi rgyud du gyur pa/ sangs rgyas thams cad kyi rigs yang dag par 'dzin pa/ byang chub sems dpa' thams cad kyi mos pa yang dag par skyed pa; de bzhin gshegs pa thams cad kyi dge ba'i rtsa ba'i rjes su song ba/ nges par rtogs pa/ sangs rgyas thams cad kyi rigs la mkhas par gyur pa yin te/ kye rgyal ba'i sras dag/ 'di ni/ byang chub sems dpa' sems dpa' chen po rnams kyi dad pa'i gter te/ de la gnas pa'i byang chub sems dpa' rnams ni/ sangs rgyas kyi chos thams cad thos par gyur na/ bden par khong du chud de/ sems can thams cad la rnam par dbye ba'i phyir nan tan du byed par 'gyur ro/ /

“Once they have attained this faith, their minds do not regress, their minds do not become confused; they cannot be broken down, they have no attachments. They always have a fundamental basis, they follow the sages, they dwell in the house of the enlightened, they maintain the lineage of all Buddhas, they increase the faith and resolution of all enlightening beings, they conform to the virtues of all enlightened ones, they set forth the enlightening techniques of the Buddhas. This is called the treasury of faith of great enlightening beings. When enlightening beings abide in this treasury of faith, they can hear and retain all the Buddha teachings, explain them to sentient beings, and cause them all to awaken to understanding.

kye rgyal ba'i sras dag/ de la byang chub sems dpa' rnams kyi tshul khrims kyi gter gang zhe na/ kye rgyal ba'i sras dag / 'di la byang chub sems dpa' thog mar phun sum tshogs pa'i tshul khrims dang ldan pa yin; byin gyis ma brlabs pa'i tshul khrims dang ldan pa yin/ mi gnas pa'i tshul khrims dang ldan pa yin/ lhag par lta ba med pa'i tshul khrims dang ldan pa yin/ 'gal ba med pa'i tshul khrims dang ldan pa yin/ gzhan la mi gnod pa'i tshul khrims dang ldan pa yin/ ma 'dres pa'i tshul khrims dang ldan pa yin/ nye ba'i nyon mongs pa med pa'i tshul khrims dang ldan pa yin/ skyon med pa'i tshul khrims dang ldan pa yin/ kha na ma tho ba med pa'i tshul khrims dang ldan pa yin/

“What is the enlightening beings’ treasury of ethics? Enlightening beings perfect the ethic of universal benefit, the ethic of not accepting wrong precepts, the ethic of nondwelling, the ethic of no regret or resentment, the ethic of noncontention, the ethic of noninjury, the ethic of nondefilement, the ethic of noncovetousness, the ethic of impeccability, and the ethic of nontransgression of moral precepts.

kye rgyal ba'i sras dag / ji ltar na; byang chub sems dpa' thog mar phun sum tshogs pa'i tshul khrims dang ldan pa yin zhe na/ kye rgyal ba'i sras dag / 'di la byang chub sems dpa' thog ma nyid du sems can thams cad la phan pa dang bde bar sems pa'o/ / kye rgyal ba'i sras dag/ ji ltar na/ byang chub sems dpa' byin gyis ma brlabs pa'i tshul khrims dang ldan pa yin zhe na/ mu stegs can gyi gnas dang mi 'dra ba'i tshul khrims yin te/ de ni/ 'di ltar rang bzhin gyis dus gsum mnyam pa nyid du go cha bgos shing spyod pa'o/ / ji ltar na; byang chub sems dpa' mi gnas pa'i tshul khrims dang ldan pa yin zhe na/ kye rgyal ba'i sras dag / 'di la 'dod pa'i khams la mi gnas pa'i tshul khrims can yin/ gzugs kyi khams la mi gnas pa'i tshul khrims can yin/ gzugs med pa'i khams la mi gnas pa'i tshul khrims can yin/ de ci'i phyir zhe na/ 'khor de dag la bag gir bya ba med de; de ltar na/ byang chub sems dpa' mi gnas pa'i tshul khrims dang ldan pa yin no/ / kye rgyal ba'i sras dag/ ji ltar na byang chub sems dpa' lhag par lta ba med ba'i tshul khrims dang ldan pa yin zhe na/ 'di la byang chub sems dpa' 'gyod pa med pa'i rgyu dang ldan pa yin te/ de ci'i phyir zhe na/ de ni/ 'di ltar mtshams med pa'i las mngon par 'du mi byed de/ tshul khrims lhod pa la gzhol ba ma yin no/ / de ltar na/ byang chub sems dpa' lhag par lta ba med pa'i tshul khrims dang ldan pa yin no/ / ji ltar na; byang chub sems dpa' 'gal ba med pa'i tshul khrims dang ldan pa yin zhe na/ 'di la byang chub sems dpa' ma bcas pa ni/ 'cha' bar mi byed/ bcas ba ni; gcod par mi byed de/ de ni/ mya ngan las 'das pa'i mthar thug tu ji ltar mthun pa'i chos dang ldan pa yin no/ / gang gis pha rol gyi sdug bsngal gyi rgyur 'gyur ba dang; pha rol 'khrug par 'gyur ba'i tshul khrims de lta bu dam bca' ba la dam bcas shing mi gnas te/ de ni/ 'di ltar pha rol gyi sems dad par bya ba'i phyir tshul khrims yang dag par len par byed do/ / ji ltar na/ byang chub sems dpa' gzhan la mi gnod pa'i tshul khrims dang ldan pa yin zhe na/ 'di la byang chub sems dpa' sems can thams cad gtse ba'i phyir tshul khrims kyi rig sngags dang / gsang sngags dang / sman gyi sbyor ba de lta bu mi sgrub kyi/ de ni/ sems can thams cad bskyab pa'i phyir tshul khrims yang dag par blangs te gnas so/ / ji ltar na/ byang chub sems dpa' ma 'dres pa'i tshul khrims dang ldan pa yin zhe na/ 'di la byang chub sems dpa' chad par lta ba dang / rtag par lta ba dang 'dres pa'i tshul khrims yang dag par len par mi byed de/ de ni/ 'di ltar rten cing 'brel bar 'byung ba la brten pa'i tshul khrims yang dag par len to/ / ji ltar na/ byang chub sems dpa' nye ba'i nyon mongs pa med pa'i tshul khrims dang ldan pa yin zhe na/ yon tan med pa bstan par bya ba'i phyir gzhan gyi sems la lta zhing rtog pa rnam pa sna tshogs su 'gyur ba ma yin no/ / de ni/ 'di ltar chos kyis ngoms pa dang ldan pa yin te/ 'byung ba'i lam tshol zhing sbyor ba'i tshul khrims yang dag par blangs te gnas so/ / ji ltar na/ byang chub sems dpa' skyon med pa'i tshul khrims dang ldan pa yin zhe na/ 'di la byang chub sems dpa' tshul khrims des log pa'i tshul khrims nye bar bzung ste gang gis pha rol po dma' ba'i tshul can du 'gyur bar bdag la mi bstod/ gzhan la mi smod do/ / de ni/ 'di ltar g.yeng ba med pa nye bar bzung ste tshul khrims yang dag par blangs shing gnas so/ / ji ltar na/ byang chub sems dpa' kha na ma tho ba med pa'i tshul khrims dang ldan pa yin zhe na/ 'di la byang chub sems dpa' srog gcod pa yongs su spangs pa yin te/ ma byin par len pa dang / 'dod pas log par g.yem pa dang / brdzun du smra ba dang / phra ma'i tshig dang / ngag brlang ba dang / tshig kyal ba dang / chags sems dang / gnod sems dang / log par lta ba yongs su spangs pa yin te/ dge ba bcu'i las kyi lam yang dag par blangs te gnas so/ / de ltar na/ byang chub sems dpa' kha na ma tho ba med pa'i tshul khrims dang ldan pa yin/ de 'di snyam du sems skyed de/ gang ji snyam du sems can rnams tshul khrims ngan pa can la yi dam 'cha' zhing / spyod pa thams cad ni/ phyin ci log gi rgyu las byung ba ste/ de ltar sangs rgyas bcom ldan 'das rnams kyis thugs su chud de phyin ci log tu gyur pa'i sems can rnams ni/ tshul khrims log pa la spyod kyi/ bdag gis ni/ ci nas kyang bla na med pa yang dag par rdzogs pa'i byang chub tu mngon par sangs rgyas te/ de bzhin nyid kyi don du chos bstan par 'gyur ba de ltar bya'o/ / snyam mo/ / kye rgyal pa'i sras dag/ 'di ni/ byang chub sems dpa' rnams kyi tshul khrims kyi gter te/ gnyis pa'o/ /

“What is the ethic of universal benefit? The enlightening beings accept and uphold pure ethics fundamentally for the sake of benefiting all living beings. What is the ethic of not accepting false precepts? The enlightening beings do not accept or practice precepts of cultists; they only exert themselves naturally in maintaining the impartial, pure precepts of the Buddhas of past, present, and future. What is the ethic of nondwelling? When the enlightening beings accept and keep ethical precepts, their minds do not dwell in the realm of desire, they don’t dwell in the realm of form, they don’t dwell in the formless realm. Why? Because they don’t keep precepts in hopes of being born there in those realms. What is the ethic of no regret or resentment? The enlightening beings always abide peacefully in a state of mind free from regret and resentment. Why? Because they don’t commit serious wrongdoings, they don’t practice flattery or deception, and they don’t break the pure precepts. What is the ethic of noncontention? The enlightening beings do not deny what has been previously established, and do not innovate—their minds always follow the precepts which are directed toward nirvana, keeping them without transgression. They do not afflict other beings by their keeping of precepts—they keep ethical precepts with the sole desire that all beings be joyful. What is the ethic of noninjury? The enlightening beings do not harm sentient beings on account of their precepts, or by learning charms, or by making drugs. They only keep ethical precepts for the purpose of saving and protecting all living beings. What is the ethic of nondefilement? The enlightening beings do not cling to extreme or biased views, they do not keep impure precepts: they only contemplate interdependent origination and keep emancipating precepts. What is the ethic of noncovetousness? The enlightening beings do not display extraordinary signs to make a show of virtue; they only keep ethical precepts for the purpose of fulfilling the way to emancipation. What is the ethic of impeccability? The enlightening beings do not boast of themselves as upholding precepts, and when they see those who break the precepts they do not scorn or shame them. They only make their minds single and keep the ethical precepts. What is the ethic of nontransgression? The enlightening beings forever cease killing, stealing, sexual misconduct, lying, two-faced talk, slander, meaningless talk, greed, anger, and false views: they fully accept the precepts of ten kinds of virtuous actions. When enlightening beings observe this ethic of nontransgression, they think, ‘Sentient beings’ transgressions of pure morality are all due to delusion. Only a Buddha is able to know why sentient beings become deluded and transgress pure morality. I should accomplish supreme enlightenment and extensively explain the truth to sentient beings, to free them from delusion.’ This is called the great enlightening beings’ second treasury, of ethics.

kye rgyal ba'i sras dag/ de la byang chub sems dpa' rnams kyi ngo tsha shes pa'i gter gang zhe na/ kye rgyal ba'i sras dag/ 'di la byang chub sems dpa' sngon gyi mtha'i spyod pa nye bar bzung ste/ gang 'di tshe rabs kyi 'khor ba thog pa ma dang tha ma med pa rgyas par ma dang 'grogs pa dang / pha dang 'grogs pa dang / zhang po dang 'grogs pa dang / srid mo dang 'grogs pa dang / spun dang 'grogs pa dang / bu dang 'grogs pa dang / bu mo dang 'grogs par gyur kyang gcig la gcig 'tshe ba dang / gcig la gcig kyal ka byed pa dang / gcig la gcig gnod pa byed pa dang / gcig la gcig 'khrig pa dang / gcig la gcig bsngo ba dang / gcig la gcig 'jig pa dang / gcig la gcig 'bod pa dang / gcig la gcig za ba dang / gcig la gcig dbang ba dang / gcig la gcig 'khol bar gyur pa de yang 'dod chags kyi dbang dang / zhe sdang gi dbang dang / gti mug gi dbang dang / rgyags pa'i dbang dang / nga rgyal gyi dbang dang / 'chab pa'i dbang dang / gnya' drag gi dbang dang / phrag dog gi dbang dang / 'jungs pa'i dbang dang / g.yo'i dbang dang / sgyu'i dbang dang / mi dga' ba'i las 'di rnams shin tu blangs pa'i phyir sems can dag gcig la gcig 'di lta bu'i rnam pa ngan pa dag nyams su myong bar gyur te/ thams cad kyang mi shes pa'i dbang gis gyur pa nas g.yo dang sgyu'i bar gyi dbang gis gyur te/ gcig la gcig bag mi byed/ rim gro mi byed/ gcig la gcig bkur sti mi byed/ gcig la gcig phud dud mi byed/ gcig la gcig btsam pa med pa dang / gcig la gcig mi mkhas pa dang / gcig la gcig gnod pa dang / gcig la gcig gsod pa dang / gcig la gcig dgrar byed par gyur to/ / zhes ngo tsha skyed do/ / ji ltar 'das pa'i dus na bdag dang / sems can rnams kyi rnam par ngan pa 'di lta bu'i tshul byung ba de bzhin da ltar byung ba'i dus na yang bdag dang / sems can thams cad la rnam pa ngan ba de lta bu dag yod do/ / ji ltar da ltar byung ba'i dus na bdag dang / sems can rnams la rnam par ngan pa de lta bu dag yod pa de bzhin ma 'ongs pa'i dus na yang bdag dang / sems can thams cad la rnam pa ngan pa de lta bu dag 'byang bar 'gyur te/ de ni/ 'das pa dang / ma byon pa dang / da ltar byung ba'i sangs rgyas bcom ldan 'das rnams kyis kyang thugs su chud do/ / de ltar bdag gis ngo tsha med cing mi bzod la/ sangs rgyas bcom ldan 'das 'das ba dang / ma byon pa dang / da ltar byung ba rnams kyis thugs su chud bzhin du rnam pa ngan pa 'di lta bu la gnas pa ni/ mi rigs mi cha'i/ / da ni/ bdag gis ci nas kyang bla na med pa yang dag par rdzogs pa'i byang chub tu mngon par sangs rgyas nas de bzhin nyid kyi don du sems can rnams la chos bstan par 'gyur ba de ltar bya'o/ / kye rgyal ba'i sras dag/ 'di ni/ byang chub sems dpa' rnams kyi ngo tsha shes pa'i gter te/ gsum pa'o/ /

“What is the great enlightening beings’ treasury of shame? The enlightening beings remember the wrongs they committed in the past and conceive shame. That is, they think, ‘Since beginningless past all sentient beings and I have been parents and children, brothers and sisters to each other: being full of greed, hatred, and ignorance, pride, conceit, dishonesty, deception, and all other afflictions, we have therefore harmed each other, plundering, raping, and killing, doing all manner of evil. All sentient beings are like this—because of passions and afflictions they do not respect or honor each other, they don’t agree with or obey each other, they don’t defer to each other, they don’t edify or guide each other, they don’t care for each other—they go on killing and injuring each other, being enemies and malefactors to each other. Reflecting on myself as well as other sentient beings, we act shamelessly in the past, future, and present, while the Buddhas of past, future, and present see and know it all. Now if I don’t stop this shameless behavior, the Buddhas of all times will also see me. Why do I still not stop such conduct? This will never do. I should therefore concentrate on eliminating evil and realizing complete perfect enlightenment, to expound the truth for all beings.’ This is called great enlightening beings’ third treasury, of shame.

kye rgyal ba'i sras dag/ de la byang chub sems dpa' rnams kyi khrel yod pa'i gter gang zhe na/ kye rgyal ba'i sras dag/ 'di la byang chub sems dpa' ni/ mtha' med par tshol bas khrel bar 'dzin pa yin te/ gzugs btsal ba dang / sgra dang / dri dang / ro dang / reg bya btsal ba dang / bu dang bu mo'i don du btsal ba dang / nor dang / bran pho dang / bran mo dang / g.yog yid du 'ong ba btsal pa'i phyir bdag gis kyang mi tshul mi cha ba'i gcam bu bya bar 'gyur ro/ / zhes te/ de ni/ tshol ba'i dbang du chags pa nye bar mi len to/ / zhes sdang nye bar mi len to/ / gti mug nye bar mi len to; ; de bzhin du nga rgyal dang / 'chab pa dang / phrag dog dang / 'jungs pa dang / g.yo dang / sgyu dang / gnod par bya ba nye bar mi len to/ / de ni/ 'di ltar dran pa skye ste/ gang ci yang rung ste/ sems can rnams rnam pa ngan pa de lta bu nye bar 'dzin pa thams cad ni/ ma rig pa'i dbang nas g.yo dang / sgyu dang / gnod par byed pa'i dbang gi bar gyis byung ba ste; de dag gcig la gcig bag mi byed/ rim gro mi byed/ bsti stang du mi byed/ phu dud du mi byed cing / btsam pa med de/ grogs por mi shes shing gcig la gcig nyam nga ba dang / gcig la gcig gsod pa dang / gcig la gcig dgrar len pa 'di lta bu'i rnam pa ngan pa dag nye bar len to/ / mngon par dga'o/ / mngon par zhe na to/ / tshol lo// kun tu tshol lo/ / kun tu btsal nas mngon par smon to/ / 'jal lo/ / kun tu 'jal lo/ / de ltar yang mig nyams pa de dag lam gang dang gang nas mngal gyi dri mas gos te byung ba de nyid du 'khrig pa'i chos la brten te mi gtsang ba byung ba ni/ kun gyis kyang shes so/ / de bas na/ de ltar bdag bla na med pa yang dag par rdzogs pa'i byang chub tu smon pa khrel med pa'i dbang du gyur nas 'das pa dang / ma byon pa dang / da ltar byung ba'i sangs rgyas bcom ldan 'das rnams kyi sku slu bar byed pa 'di ni/ mi rigs kyi/ da ni/ bdag gis ci nas kyang bla na med pa yang dag par rdzogs pa'i byang chub tu mngon par sangs rgyas nas de bzhin nyid kyi don du chos bstan par 'gyur ba de ltar bya'o/ / snyam mo/ / kye rgyal ba'i sras dag / 'di ni/ byang chub sems dpa' rnams kyi khrel yod pa'i gter te/ bzhi pa'o/ /

“What is the great enlightening beings’ treasury of conscience? The enlightening beings are ashamed of their insatiable desires of the past and consequent increase of all afflictions, such as greed, anger, folly, etc., and resolve that they should not act this way anymore. Also they think, ‘Sentient beings are unwise; developing afflictions, they do all sorts of bad things. They do not respect or honor each other and develop into enemies and malefactors to each other. They have committed all such evils, and are happy about it, pursuing and approving of them. Blind, having no eye of wisdom, they enter wombs in mother’s bellies and undergo birth, becoming impure corporeal beings, finally to become grey and wrinkled. Those of wisdom observe this to be simply something impure born of lust. The Buddhas of past, present, and future see and know all: if I now were to still act in these ways, I would be trying to fool the Buddhas. Therefore I should cultivate conscience, quickly attain complete perfect enlightenment, and explain the truth to all beings.’ This is called great enlightening beings’ fourth treasury, of conscience.

kye rgyal ba'i sras dag / de la byang chub sems dpa' rnams kyi thos pa'i gter gang zhe na/ kye rgyal ba'i sras dag / 'di la byang chub sems dpa' thos pa dang ldan pa yin te/ 'di yod na 'di 'byung ngo/ / 'di med na 'di mi 'byung ngo/ / 'di byung bas 'di skye'o/ / 'di 'gag pas 'di 'gag go /'di dag ni/ 'jig rten pa'i chos so/ / 'di dag ni/ 'jig rten las 'das pa'i chos so/ / 'di dag ni/ 'dus byas kyi chos so/ / 'di dag ni/ 'dus ma byas kyi chos so/ / 'di dag ni/ lung bstan pa'i chos so/ / 'di dag ni/ lung ma bstan pa'i chos so; ;

“What is the great enlightening beings’ treasury of learning? The enlightening beings know that something exists because something else exists, and that something does not exist because something else does not exist; they know that something comes to be because something else comes to be, and that something passes away because something else passes away; they know what is mundane and what is transmundane, what is compounded and what is uncompounded, what is meaningful and what is pointless.

de la ci yod pas gang 'byung bar 'gyur zhe na/ ma rig pa yod pas 'du byed rnams 'byung ngo/ / ci med pas gang med par 'gyur zhe na/ rnam par shes pa med pas ming dang gzugs med par 'gyur ro/ / ci skyes pas gang skye bar 'gyur zhe na/ sred pa skyes pas sdug bsngal skye'o/ / ci 'gags pas gang 'gag par 'gyur zhe na/ srid pa 'gags pas skye ba 'gag go/

“What does it mean that something exists because something else exists? It means that when there is ignorance there is conditioning. What does it mean that because something does not exist something else does not exist? It means that when there is no discriminating consciousness there is no name and form. What does it mean that something comes to be because something else comes to be? It means that when craving comes to be suffering comes to be. What does it mean that something passes away because something else passes away? It means that when becoming passes away birth passes away.

de la 'jig rten pa'i chos rnams gang zhe na/ gzugs dang / tshor ba dang / 'du shes dang / 'du byed dang / rnam par shes pa'o/ / de la 'jig rten las 'das pa'i chos rnams gang zhe na/ 'di lta ste/ tshul khrims kyi phung po dang / ting nge 'dzin gyi phung po dang / shes rab kyi phung po dang / rnam par grol ba'i phung po dang / rnam par grol ba'i ye shes mthong ba'i phung po ste/ 'di dag ni/ 'jig rten las 'das pa'i chos so/ / 'dus byas kyi chos rnams gang zhe na/ 'di lta ste/ 'dod pa'i khams dang / gzugs kyi khams dang / gzugs med pa'i khams dang / sems can gyi khams te/ 'di dag ni/ 'dus byas kyi chos so/ / 'dus ma byas kyi chos rnams gang zhe na/ nam mkha' dang / mya ngan las 'das pa dang / so sor brtags te 'gog pa dang / so sor ma brtags par 'gog pa dang / rten cing 'brel bar 'byung ba dang / chos kyi gnas nyid de/ 'di dag ni / 'dus ma byas pa'i chos so/ /

“What are mundane phenomena? Material form, sensation, perception, conditioning, and consciousness. What are transmundane phenomena? Discipline, concentration, wisdom, liberation, and the knowledge and insight of liberation. What are compounded things? The realm of desire, the realm of form, the formless realm, and the realm of sentient beings. What are uncompounded things? Space, nirvana, extinction by analysis, extinction because of lack of conditions, and the subsistence of the nature of things, interdependent origination.

lung bstan pa'i chos rnams gang zhe na/ 'phags pa'i bden pa bzhi dang / dge sbyong gi 'bras bu bzhi dang / tha dad pa yang dag par shes pa bzhi dang / mi 'jigs pa bzhi dang / dran pa nye bar gzhag pa bzhi dang / yang dag par spong ba bzhi dang / rdzu 'phrul gyi rkang pa bzhi dang / dbang po lnga dang / stobs lnga dang / byang chub kyi yan lag bdun dang / 'phags pa'i lam yan lag brgyad de/ 'di dag ni/ lung bstan pa'i chos so/ /

“What are things with meaning? The four holy truths, the four fruits of ascesis, the four special knowledges, the four fearlessnesses, the four points of mindfulness, the four right efforts, the four bases of spiritual powers, the five faculties and five powers, the seven branches of enlightenment, and the eightfold path of sages.

lung ma bstan pa'i chos rnams gang zhe na/ 'jig rten mtha' yod pa dang / 'jig rten mtha' med pa dang / mtha' yod pa'ang ma yin/ mtha' med pa'ang ma yin pa zhes bya ba 'di ni/ lung du ma bstan pa'o/ / 'jig rten rtag pa dang / 'jig rten mi rtag pa dang / rtag pa'ang yin la/ mi rtag pa'ang yin pa dang / rtag pa'ang ma yin la/ mi rtag pa'ang ma yin pa zhes bya ba 'di ni/ lung ma bstan pa'o/ / de bzhin gshegs pa shi phan chad yod pa dang / de bzhin gshegs pa shi phan chad med pa dang / de bzhin gshegs pa shi phan chad yod kyang yod la/ med kyang med pa dang / de bzhin gshegs pa shi phan chad yod pa'ang ma yin/ med pa'ang ma yin pa zhes bya ba ni/ lung ma bstan pa'o/ / bdag dang sems can rnams yod pa dang / bdag dang sems can rnams med pa dang / bdag dang sems can rnams yod pa'ang yin la/ med pa'ang yin pa dang / bdag dang sems can rnams yod pa'ang ma yin; med pa'ang ma yin pa zhes bya ba 'di ni/ lung ma bstan pa'o/ / sangs rgyas ji snyed cig yongs su mya ngan las 'das/ rang sangs rgyas ji snyed cig yongs su mya ngan las 'das nyan thos ji snyed cig yongs su mya ngan las 'das/ sangs rgyas ji snyed cig ma byon/ rang sangs rgyas ji snyed cig ma byon/ nyan thos ji snyed cig ma byon/ byang chub sems dpa' ji snyed cig skye bar 'gyur/ sangs rgyas ji snyed cig bzhugs/ rang sangs rgyas ji snyed cig bzhugs/ nyan thos ji snyed cig bzhugs/ byang chub sems dpa' ji snyed cig bzhugs/ sangs rgyas dag pas su snga/ rang sangs rgyas dag pas su snga/ nyan thos dag pas su snga/ byang chub sems dpa' dag pas su snga/ sangs rgyas dag pas su 'phyi/ rang sangs rgyas dag pas su 'phyi/ nyan thos dag pas su 'phyi/ sems can dag pas su 'phyi/ chos dag pas su snga/ 'jig rten gang nas 'ongs/ 'jig rten gang du 'gro /'jig rten gyi khams ji snyed cig chags par 'gyur/ 'jig rten gyi khams ji snyed cig gnas pa yin/ 'jig rten gyi khams gang nas 'ongs/ 'jig rten gyi khams gang zhig yongs su zad par 'gyur/ 'khor ba'i sngon gyi mtha' ni/ gang / 'khor ba'i phyi ma'i mtha' ni/ gang zhes bya ba 'di ni/ lung du ma bstan pa'o/ / de 'di ltar dran pa skye ste/ sems can gang su'ang rung ste/ kun tu rgyug pa dang / kun tu 'khor ba thams cad ni/ chos 'di dag mi shes pa'i phyir te/ de ltar thos pa dang mi ldan pa'i so so'i skye bo rnams kun tu rgyug go /kun tu 'khor ro/ / de bas na/ de ni/ bdag gis ci nas kyang bsam pa thams cad thos pa'i mdzod bzung ste bla na med pa yang dag par rdzogs pa'i byang chub tu mngon par sangs rgyas nas de bzhin nyid kyi don du chos bstan par bya'o/ / zhes bya ba 'di ni/ kye rgyal ba'i sras dag/ byang chub sems dpa' rnams kyi thos pa'i gter te/ lnga pa'o/ /

“What are pointless issues? Whether the world is finite or infinite, or both, or neither; whether the world is permanent or impermanent, or both, or neither; whether a Buddha exists after nirvana or not, whether a Buddha both does and does not exist or neither does nor does not exist after nirvana; whether oneself and sentient beings exist or not, whether they both do and do not exist, whether they neither do nor do not exist; how many Buddhas attained final nirvana in the past, how many listeners and individual illuminates attain final nirvana, how many Buddhas, listeners, individual illuminates, and sentient beings there are presently existing; what Buddhas appeared first, what listeners and individual illuminates appeared first; what Buddhas will appear last, what listeners and individual illuminates will appear last; where the world came from, where the world will go; how many worlds have come to be, how many worlds have perished, where did the worlds come from, where did the worlds go; what the very beginning of birth and death is, what the very end of birth and death will be—these all are called pointless issues. Great enlightening beings form this thought: ‘Sentient beings haven’t much learning in regard to birth and death and are not capable of knowing all these things. I should determine to sustain the treasury of learning, realize unexcelled complete perfect enlightenment, and expound the truth to sentient beings.’ This is called great enlightening beings’ fifth treasury, of learning.

kye rgyal ba'i sras dag / de la byang chub sems dpa' rnams kyi gtong ba'i gter gang zhe na/ kye rgyal ba'i sras dag / 'di la byang chub sems dpa' gtong ba dang ldan pa yin/ yongs su gtong ba dang ldan pa yin/ nang gi gtong ba dang ldan pa yin/ phyi rol gyi gtong ba dang ldan pa yin/ phyi nang gi gtong ba dang ldan pa yin/ thams cad gtong ba dang ldan pa yin/ 'das pa gtong ba dang ldan pa yin/ ma 'ongs pa gtong ba dang ldan pa yin/ da ltar byung ba gtong ba dang ldan pa yin/ shin tu gtong pa dang ldan pa yin te/ kye rgyal pa'i sras dag /

“What is the great enlightening beings’ treasury of giving? The enlightening beings practice ten kinds of giving: partial giving, exhaustive giving, inside giving, outside giving, inside and outside giving, total giving, past giving, future giving, present giving, and ultimate giving.

ji ltar na/ byang chub sems dpa' gtong ba dang ldan pa yin zhe na/ kye rgyal ba'i sras dag/ 'di la byang chub sems dpa' rang bzhin gyis bgo bsha' byed pa'i ngang tshul can yin te/ de rtag tu bgo bsha' byas shing bdag kyang shes kyis spyod pa yin te/ bdag bde bar bya ba dang / bdag yongs su sbyang ba dang / bdag rim gro bya ba'i phyir yo byad ji snyed du bsags pa de dag thams cad kyang bgo bsha' byas shing spyod kyi/ ma bgos par ni/ ma yin no/ / de dag spyod pa'i tshe'ang sems 'di snyam du skyed de/ lus 'di la srin bu'i rigs rnam pa sna tshogs brgyad cu gnas te/ de dag kyang bdag gi lus 'di bde bas ni/ bde bar 'gyur bdag gi lus 'di sdug bsngal bas ni/ sdug bsngal bar 'gyur ro/ / zhes de gang ci la spyod pa de dag thams cad kyang myong ba med pa'i sems kyis de dag mi 'chi ba dang / de dag bde bar bya ba'i phyir gtong ngo/ / gzhan yang de 'di snyam du sems te/ yun ring po nas zas dang lus bde ba la chags par gyur gyi/ da ni/ bdag gi lus la chags pa las rnam par 'da' bar bya'o/ / zhes bya ba 'di ni/ gtong ba'o/ /

“What is enlightening beings’ partial giving? They are benevolent and kind by nature and are very generous. If they receive fine food, they don’t take it all themselves—they want to share it with others, and only then will they eat. The same applies to everything they may receive. When they eat, they think. ‘There are countless microorganisms in my body whose life depends on me. If my body is satisfied, so are they. If my body is hungry or in pain, so are they. May this food which I now receive enable all beings to be satisfied; I myself eat this in order to distribute it to them, without greed for the taste.’ They also think, ‘Throughout the long night of ignorance I have been attached to this body and want to satisfy it, so I take food and drink. Now I bestow this food on living beings, so that I may forever end covetousness and attachment.’ This is called partial giving.

byang chub sems dpa'i yongs su gtong ba gang zhe na/ 'di la byang chub sems dpa' la zas sam/ skom mam; bza' ba'am/ bca' ba'am/ bldag pa'am/ btung ba'am/ gzhib pa'am/ myang ba'am/ gos sam/ phreng ba'am/ byug pa'am/ rgyan nam/ ci'ang rung ste/ gang spyad na ni/ 'tsho'i/ ma spyad na ni/ 'chi bar 'gyur ba zhig nye bar gnas par gyur la/ de'i tshe slong ba zhig 'ongs te/ de la ci nas kyang zad par 'gyur ba dang; lhag ma med par bslangs kyang de la byang chub sems dpa' 'di snyam du sems te/ sngon gyi mtha' de dag tu bdag bkres pas shi bar gyur pa yang dmigs pas mi sleb ste/ su la yang phan par ma gyur to/ / da 'di ltar rim pas sngon chad myong ba'i chos can dang mnyam pa nyid kyis dus byas par gyur la/ sems can de dag kyang bde bar gyur na/ bdag gis thob par bya ba legs par thob bo/ / bdag gi 'di dag kyang zad kyang rung / 'chi ba'i mthar yang thug kyang rung ste/ sems can rnams 'tsho bar bya'o; ; zhes gtong ba 'di ni/ yongs su gtong ba'o/ /

“What is enlightening beings’ exhaustive giving? They get various kinds of fine food, incense, flowers, clothes, and other necessities of life—if they use them themselves, they can live out their years in comfort; if they give them up and pass them on to others, they will suffer want and die. Sometimes there may be people who come and say, ‘You should give me everything you have’—the enlightening beings think to themselves, ‘Since beginningless past I have died of starvation countless times without having the benefit of being able to help anyone at all. Now I shall again give up my life as I have in the past, so I should do it for the sake of helping sentient beings.’ So they give away all they have, even to the point of ending life. This is called exhaustive giving.

byang chub sems dpa'i nang gi gtong ba gang zhe na/ 'di la byang chub sems dpa' dar zhing bzang por gnas pa/ gzugs mdzes pa/ blta na sdug pa/ mdog rgyas pa gya nom pa dang ldan pa/ khrus dang byug pa legs par byas pa/ phreng ba dang rgyan legs par btags pa/ gos gsar pa ma bab pa bgos pa/ gling bzhi pa'i 'jig rten gyi khams su rgyal por dbang bskur bas dbang bskur pa/ rin po che bdun dang ldan pa de lta bu'i drung du slong ba dag cig 'ongs te 'di skad du/ bdag cag ni/ na bas gzir to/ / rgas so/ / 'khogs so/ / sdug bsngal gyis mnar to/ / nad tshabs che'o/ / nad g.yog med do/ / 'chi la thug go /gal te khyod kyi lus las lag pa'am/ rkang pa'am/ sha'am/ khrag gam/ mgo'am/ klad pa'am/ rus pa'am/ rkang ngam/ su la ci dgos pa de dag khyer cig ces rgyal po la thag thogs med par rang gi lus bdag cag la byin na/ lus 'dis bdag cag nad 'di las ldang bar 'gyur ro/ / zhes zer na/ kye rgyal ba'i sras dag / 'di la byang chub sems dpa' 'di snyam du sems te/ lus 'di lta zhig chos kyi de 'dra bar 'gyur yang su la yang phan par ma gyur gyi/ da ni/ de lta bu'i chos can gyi lus 'dis sems can 'di dag bde bar 'gyur bar bya'o/ / zhes nas de la sems bskyed pa 'ga' tsam yang 'gyod par 'gyur ba med pa 'di ni/ nang gi gtong ba zhes bya'o/ /

“What is enlightening beings’ inside giving? When the enlightening beings are young vigorous, and good looking, adorned with scents, flowers, and clothing, and have just received coronation as universal sovereigns, having all the seven treasures of universal monarchs, reigning over the four quarters, if someone should come and say, ‘O great sovereign, know that I am old and feeble, seriously ill, alone and helpless, worn out, not far from death: if I were to receive the hands and feet, blood and flesh, head, eyes, bones, and marrow from the king’s body, my life would be saved. Please don’t deliberate further and do not begrudge me this—just look upon me with compassion and give them to me.’ At such a time the enlightening beings would think, ‘This body of mine will in the end surely die, without any benefit. I should take the opportunity to give it away early to save a living being.’ With this thought they give without regret. This is called inside giving.

de la byang chub sems dpa'i phyi rol gyi gtong pa gang zhe na/ 'di la byang chub sems dpa' gzhung de bzhin du rgya cher dbang bskur ba dang / 'khor los bsgyur ba'i srid la gnas pa/ gling bzhi la dbang ba/ rin po che bdun dang bde ba'i yo byad thams cad dang ldan pa/ thog ma mngon par dbang bskur ba de lta bu'i drung du slong ba dag cig lhags te 'di skad du/ bdag ni/ bkren no/ / dbul lo/ / shin tu sdug bsngal lo/ / nor dang mi ldan no/ / khyod ni/ bde ba'i yo byad thams cad dang ldan na/ byams bu gling bzhi'i 'khor los bsgyur ba'i srid bdag cag la byin te/ phyis 'di la dbang mi bsgyur bar byas na/ des ni/ bdag cag bde bar 'gyur ro/ / zhes zer na/ de la byang chub sems dpa' 'di snyam du sems te; phun sum tshogs pa thams cad ni/ zad pa'i mthar 'gyur te/ de'i tshe ni/ su'i bsam pa yang yongs su mgu bar bya bar mi nus kyi/ bdag gis da ni/ 'phral du sems can 'di dag gi bsam pa yongs su tshim par bya'o zhes nas de'i rgyus sems bskyed pa 'ga' tsam 'gyod par 'gyur ba med par gtong ba 'di ni/ phyi rol gyi gtong ba zhes bya'o/ /

“What is enlightening beings’ outside giving? When enlightening beings are in full maturity and physical well being, replete with all marks of dignity, adorned with fine flowers and excellent clothing, having been crowned as universal monarchs regining over the four quarters, having all the seven treasures, should someone come and say, ‘I am poor and oppressed by all kinds of miseries; please be so kind and compassionate as to give up your rank to me, so that I may reign and experience the felicities of sovereignty,’ the enlightening beings think, ‘All flourishing and prosperity must inevitably decline and end. When it does decline and end, it is no longer possible to benefit sentient beings. I should satisfy this person as he requests.’ And having formed this thought, they give up the throne without regret. This is called outside giving.

de la byang chub sems dpa'i phyi nang gi gtong ba gang zhe na/ 'di la byang chub sems dpa' 'khor los bsgyur ba'i srid la de ltar dbang bskur ba/ bde ba'i yo byad thams cad dang ldan pa/ bsag par bya ba rnam par bsags pa de lta bu'i drung du slong ba dag cig 'ongs nas 'di skad du/ khyod kyis ni/ 'khor los bsgyur ba'i rgyal po sngon chad kyang myong / bdag cag ni/ dge ba ma myong ba yin na/ byams bu 'khor los bsgyur ba'i srid bdag cag la byin la/ khyod kyis bdag cag rim gror bya ba dang / bsnyen bkur bar gyis shig ces zer na/ de la byang chub sems dpa' 'di snyam du sems te/ bdag gi lus kyi chos nyid dang / srid kyi chos nyid de dag thams cad kyang tha mar med par 'gyur ba ste/ lus kyang rjes su 'brang bar gnas la/ srid kyang che zhing slong ba rnams kyang mngon du gyur pa 'di'i tshe snying po med pa las snying po blang bar bya'o/ / zhes nas de'i rgyus sems bskyed pa 'ga' tsam yang 'gyod par 'gyur ba med par rim gro byed cing gtong ba 'di ni/ byang chub sems dpa'i phyi nang gi gtong ba zhes bya'o/ /

“What is enlightening beings’ inside and outside giving? When the enlightening beings are in the position of universal monarch, as explained before, if someone comes and says, ‘You have been in the rank of universal monarch for a long time, and I have never been. Please abdicate in my favor, and be my attendant.’ At that time the enlightening beings think, ‘My body, wealth, and rank are all impermanent. I am now in my prime, wealthy, in possession of the whole world. Now a beggar appears before me; I should, through these perishable things, seek the imperishable truth.’ And so thinking, they abdicate, personally work respectfully as servants, without regret. This is called inside and outside giving.

de la byang chub sems dpa'i thams cad gtong ba gang zhe na/ 'di la byang chub sems dpa' 'khor los bsgyur ba'i rgyal srid la de ltar dbang bskur zhing / bde ba thams cad dang ldan pa de lta bu'i drung du slong ba dag cig lhags te 'di skad du/ bdag cag ni/ khyod kyi legs pa dang yon tan snyan pa thos nas grong dang / grong khyer dang / ljongs dang / khams dang / rgyal po'i gnas du ma nas khyod ni/ gdon mi za bar bdag cag gi bsam pa yongs su tshim par byed par 'gyur snyam ste/ 'dir phyin na/ byams bu khyod kyis bdag cag gi bsam pa yongs su rdzogs par gyis shig ces nas la la ni/ bdag cag la rin po che bdun dgos so/ / zhes zer/ la la ni/ bdag cag la gling bzhi dgos so/ / zhes zer la la ni/ bdag cag la rgyal po'i bu dgos so/ / zhes zer/ la la ni/ bdag cag la rgyal po'i mig gnyis dgos so/ / zhes zer/ la la ni/ bdag cag la rgyal po'i lag pa gnyis dgos so/ / zhes zer/ la la ni; bdag cag la rgyal po'i rkang pa gnyis dgos so/ / zhes zer/ la la ni/ bdag cag la rgyal po'i sha dgos so/ / zhes zer/ la la ni/ bdag cag la rgyal po'i khrag dgos so/ / zhes zer/ la la ni/ bdag cag la rgyal po'i mgo dgos so/ / zhes zer/ la la ni/ bdag cag la rgyal po'i snying dgos so/ / zhes zer na/ de la byang chub sems dpa' 'di snyam du sems te/ sdug pa dang / yid du 'ong ba thams cad dang bral zhing bye bar yang gyur te/ sems can gang gi bsam pa yang yongs su tshim par ma gyur gyi/ da ni/ bdag gi lus 'bral bar 'gyur ba'i chos can 'dis sems can de dag gi chags sems rtse gzhil bar bya ba'i phyir bsam pa yongs su tshim par bya'o/ / bcol ba dang ldan pa'i chos kyi gnas su ni/ sems bskyed par mi bya'o/ / zhes nas de dag thams cad gtong yang de'i phyir de la sems bskyed pa gcig tsam yang 'gyod par 'gyur ba med de/ sems can gang la yang rim gro med par mi byed pa de ni/ byang chub sems dpa'i thams cad gtong ba'o/ /

“What is the enlightening beings’ total giving? The enlightening beings are in the rank of universal monarchs, as described before, and countless poor people come and say, ‘The fame of the monarch is heard throughout the world, and we have come here because of your reputation. We each have requests which we hope you will compassionately fulfill.’ Then those poor people variously ask the monarch for the land, for his wife and children, for his hands and feet, blood, flesh, heart, lungs, head, eyes, marrow, and brains. At such a time, the enlightening beings think, ‘All who love must eventually part, with no benefit to sentient beings. Now I want to give up all clinging, and fulfill the wishes of sentient beings with these things which I must in any case eventually lose’. Having thus reflected, they give all, without regret or resentment, and without looking down on sentient beings. This is called total giving.

de la byang chub sems dpa'i 'das pa gtong ba gang zhe na/ 'di la byang chub sems dpa' sangs rgyas bcom ldan 'das 'das pa rnams kyi byang chub sems dpa'i spyod pa thos pa dang / 'das pa'i sangs rgyas bcom ldan 'das rnams kyi phun sum tshogs pa thams cad nyan cing thos nas de dag thams cad la chags par mi byed/ 'bral bar mi byed/ dmigs su med pas rab tu 'jug ste/ rtog par mi byed/ rnam par rtog par mi byed/ yongs su rtog par mi byed/ smon par mi byed/ chags par mi byed/ zhen par mi byed/ rten pa'i sems kyis gnas par mi byed de/ rmi lam gyi chos de lta bu thob par byed kyang dge ba'i rtsa ba de dag la snying po'i 'du shes mi skyed do/ / dge ba'i rtsa ba de dag la rten pa'i 'du shes su mi byed de/ 'on kyang rten pa'i sems can rnams gzung ba dang / sangs rgyas kyi chos kyang yongs su smin par bya ba'i phyir brjod do/ / 'chad do/ / ston to/ / 'das pa'i chos nyid la brtags na/ shar phyogs su mi mthong ngo/ / lho phyogs dang / nub phyogs dang / byang phyogs su rjes su mi mthong ngo/ / byang shar gyi phyogs mtshams dang / shar lho'i phyogs mtshams dang / lho nub kyi phyogs mtshams dang / nub byang gi phyogs mtshams dang / 'og dang steng gi phyogs su rjes su mi mthong ste/ de 'di snyam du/ gang ci yang rung ma btang ba de ni/ btang ba'o/ / snyam du sems te/ kye rgyal ba'i sras dag / 'di ni/ byang chub sems dpa'i 'das pa gtong ba'o/ /

“What is the enlightening beings’ past giving? The enlightening beings, having heard of the accomplishments and virtues of the Buddhas and enlightening beings of the past, are not attached to them, realizing they are not existent. They do not create discrimination, do not covet, crave, or seek them. They depend on nothing. They see things as like dreams, without solidity. They do not conceive of roots of goodness as existent, and they do not rely on them; however, they fulfill the teachings of Buddhas and expound them in order to teach and edify grasping, clinging sentient beings. Also they contemplate all things of the past, searching them out everywhere to find they cannot be apprehended. Having reflected thus, they ultimately relinquish all things of the past. This is called past giving.

de la byang chub sems dpa'i ma 'ongs pa gtong ba gang zhe na/ 'di la byang chub sems dpa' sangs rgyas bcom ldan 'das ma byon pa rnams kyi spyod pa nyan na/ mtshan ma'i tshul dang dngos por 'dzin pas mi 'dzin te/ 'jig rten gyi khams gzhan la brtson par mi byed pa yin; tshol ba mi mnga' ba yin/ 'dod chags pa'i sems kyis mi smon pa yin/ de la sems mi sdud pa yin te/ myong bar mi byed do/ / smon par mi byed do/ / de dag tu dge ba'i rtsa ba rnams mi gtong ngo/ / de dag tu dge ba'i rtsa ba rnams 'jug par mi byed de/ spyod pa'ang rgyun gcod par mi byed do/ / 'on kyang dmigs pa des sangs rgyas kyi chos su 'grub par bya ba'i phyir te/ sems can rnams kyi bsam pa dang / tshogs sdud par byed cing chos nyid kyang rab tu sdud do/ / chos de ni/ yul na'ang mi gnas/ phyogs na yang mi gnas/ nang na yang ma yin/ phyi rol na yang ma yin/ rgyang ring po na yang ma yin/ drung na yang ma yin no/ / zhes de 'di snyam du sems te/ gang du nam yang spyad pa med par bya'o/ / snyam pa 'di ni/ ma 'ongs pa gtong ba'o/ / kye rgyal ba'i sras dag /

“What is enlightening beings’ future giving? When enlightening beings hear of the practices of Buddhas of the future, they realize they are not existent; they do not grasp their characteristics, they do not particularly delight in going to be born in the Buddhas’ lands, they do not indulge, do not cling, and yet do not disdain them; they do not dedicate virtues there, yet they do not withdraw from virtue on their account—they always cultivate practice diligently, never giving up, just wanting to include sentient beings in those realms, explain the truth to them, and cause them to master the qualities of buddhahood. And yet these qualities have no locus, yet are not without location; they are not inside or outside, not near or far. They also think that since things are not existent they cannot but be relinquished. This is called future giving.

de la byang chub sems dpa'i da ltar byung ba gtong ba gang zhe na/ kye rgyal ba'i sras dag / 'di la byang chub sems dpa' rgyal po chen po bzhi'i ris kyi lha rnams dang / sum cu rtsa gsum dang / mtshe ma dang / dga' ldan dang / 'phrul dga' dang / gzhan 'phrul dbang byed dang / tshangs pa dang / tshangs ris dang / tshangs lha nye phan dang / tshangs pa kun 'khor dang / tshangs chen dang / snang ba dang / 'od chung dang / tshad med snang ba dang / shin tu snang ba dang / dge ba dang / chung dge dang / tshad med dge ba dang / dge rgyas dang / che ba dang / chung che dang / tshad med che ba dang / 'bras bu che ba dang / mi che ba dang / mi gdung ba dang / shin tu mthong ba dang / gya nom snang ba dang / 'og min gyi lha rnams nas nyan thos kyi phun sum tshogs pa dang / rang sangs rgyas kyi phun sum tshogs pa dag kyang nyan te/ des de dag thos nas kyang rmongs par mi 'gyur/ shin tu rmongs par mi 'gyur/ rab tu rmongs par mi 'gyur/ zhum par mi 'gyur/ kun nas zhum par mi 'gyur; rnam par zhum par mi 'gyur/ shin tu zhum par mi 'gyur/ dma' bar mi 'gyur te/ 'di ltar de ni/ shes pas 'du byed du gtogs pa thams cad rmi lam lta bur mngon du byed do/ / de 'di snyam du gang sbyin par bya ba 'di ni/ su'i yang ma yin no/ / snyam ste/ ngan song gi lam nye bar gnas pa bzlog par bya ba dang / sangs rgyas kyi chos thams cad bsgrub pa'i phyir chos ston kyang byang chub sems dpa'i lam mngon du gyur pa'i phyir de la sems rgyu ba med de/ 'di ni/ da ltar byung ba gtong ba zhes bya'o/ /

“What is enlightening beings’ present giving? When the enlightening beings hear of the virtues of all the beings of various heavenly states, of Buddhist disciples and individual illuminates, their minds are not confused or absorbed, not concentrated or scattered: they only observe all actions as like dreams, unreal—they have no craving or attachment, but in order to cause sentient beings to divorce evil dispositions, they practice the enlightening path without discrimination, fulfill the Buddha teachings, and expound them. This is called present giving.

de la byang chub sems dpa'i shin tu gtong ba gang zhe na/ 'di la byang chub sems dpa' sems can mig dang mi ldan pa dang / rna ba dang mi ldan pa dang / sna dang mi ldan pa dang / lce dang mi ldan pa dang / lus dang mi ldan pa grangs med pa zhig gis 'di skad du bdag cag la ci med pa de khyod kyis byin la/ nged mi ldan pa med par gyis shig / khyod ni/ bskal pa grangs med par mi ldan par 'dug cig / ces zer na/ byang chub sems dpa' ni/ de thos ma thag tu sems can de dag mi ldan pa med par sgrub ste/ bskal pa grangs med par dbang po dang mi ldan pa de yang nyams su len to/ / de ma'i lto na 'dug pa'i tshe ji lta bur spyod pa dang / mer mer por 'dug pa ji lta bu yin pa dang / rdos par gyur pa ji lta bu yin pa dang / mkhregs par gyur pa ji lta bu yin pa dang / dbang po grub pa ji lta bu yin pa dang / skyes pa ji lta bu yin pa dang / rga ba ji lta bu yin pa dang / na ba ji lta bu yin pa dang / shi ba ji lta bu yin pa dang / lus kyi rang bzhin thog ma dang / bar ma dang / tha ma ji lta ba bzhin du yang dag par rab tu shes so// ngom du mi rung ba dang / ngo tsha skye ba/ 'phags pa ma yin pa/ dri mi zhim pa/ rjen pa'i dri can/ ror 'gyur ba/ rus pa bsags pa/ sha dang khrag gis g.yogs pa/ rma dgu nas rtag tu zag pa'o/ / zhes nas de ni/ sems bskyed pa gcig tsam gyis kyang de don du gnyer bar mi sems te/ sems bskyed pa gcig gis kyang chags pa mi skyed do/ / de shin tu gtong ba des 'dzin pa med pa'i yid dang ldan pa yin te/ lus 'di ni/ de ltar snying po med pa yin na/ bdag gis lus 'di snying po med par mngon par mthong bzhin du lus la chags par ji ltar bya/ sems can 'di dag gi bsam pa de bzhin yongs su tshim par bya'o/ / lus snying po med pa 'dis 'gro ba thams cad kyi bsam pa yongs su rdzogs par bya'o/ / 'gro ba thams cad kyis kyang shes par bya'o/ / ye shes kyi tshogs gang yang rung ba la yang mi gnas pa'i tshul gyis gzhag par bya'o/ / zhes nas lus kyi 'du shes kyang med/ sems kyi 'du shes kyang med de/ kye rgyal ba'i sras dag / 'di ni/ byang chub sems dpa'i gtong ba'i gtor te/ drug pa'o/ /

“What is enlightening beings’ ultimate giving? If innumerable sentient beings, some lacking eyes, some lacking ears, some lacking noses or tongues, or hands or feet, should come and say to the enlightening beings, ‘We are unfortunate, physically handicapped—please be so kind as to give up your organs so as to make us complete,’ the enlightening beings, hearing this, immediately give them; even if because of this they should be physically handicapped for incalculable eons, they would never have a single throught of regret. They just observe this body from its first conception, its various organs an unclean little mass of cells, which is born, ages, gets sick, and dies. They also contemplate this body as having no true reality, being shameless, lacking in sagacity, foul and unclean, held up by bones and joints, covered with blood and flesh, with nine apertures constantly flowing, despised by people. Having thus contemplated, they do not conceive a single thought of attachment. They also reflect that this body is fragile and unstable and not to be clung to, that it should be given to satisfy the wishes of others, and that this deed will guide all sentient beings and cause them to be unattached to body or mind, enabling them to develop the pure body of knowledge. This is called ultimate giving. This is the enlightening beings’ sixth treasury, of generosity.

kye rgyal ba'i sras dag/ de la byang chub sems dpa'i ye shes kyi gter gang zhe na/ 'di la byang chub sems dpa' gzugs rab tu shes so/ / gzugs kun 'byung ba rab tu shes so/ / gzugs kyi 'gog pa rab tu shes so/ / gzugs 'gog par 'gro ba'i lam yang dag pa ji lta ba bzhin du rab tu shes so/ / de bzhin du tshor ba dang / 'du shes dang / 'du byed dang / rnam par shes pa yang dag pa ji lta ba bzhin du rab tu shes so/ / rnam par shes pa'i kun 'byung ba yang dag pa ji lta ba bzhin du rab tu shes so/ / rnam par shes pa 'gog pa yang dag pa ji lta ba bzhin du rab tu shes so; ; rnam par shes pa 'gog par 'gro ba'i lam yang dag pa ji lta ba bzhin du rab tu shes so/ / ma rig pa rab tu shes so/ / ma rig pa'i kun 'byung ba rab tu shes so/ / ma rig pa 'gog pa yang dag pa ji lta ba bzhin du rab tu shes so/ / ma rig pa 'gog par 'gyur ba'i lam yang dag pa ji lta ba bzhin du rab tu shes so/ / sred pa rab tu shes so/ / sred pa kun 'byung ba rab tu shes so/ / sred pa 'gog pa rab tu shes so/ / sred pa 'gog par 'gro ba'i lam yang dag pa ji lta ba bzhin du rab tu shes so/ / nyan thos rab tu shes so/ nyan thos kyi chos rab tu shes so/ / nyan thos kyi kun 'byung ba rab tu shes so/ / nyan thos kyi mya ngan las 'da' ba yang dag pa ji lta ba bzhin du rab tu shes so/ / rang sangs rgyas rab tu shes so/ / rang sangs rgyas kyi chos rab tu shes so/ / rang sangs rgyas kyi kun 'byung ba rab tu shes so/ / rang sangs rgyas kyi yongs su mya ngan las 'da' ba yang dag pa ji lta bzhin du rab tu shes so/ / byang chub sems dpa' rab tu shes so/ / byang chub sems dpa'i chos rab tu shes so/ / byang chub sems dpa'i kun 'byung ba rab tu shes so/ / byang chub sems dpa'i yongs su mya ngan las 'da' ba yang dag pa ji lta ba bzhin du rab tu shes so/ /

“What is the great enlightening beings’ treasury of wisdom? The enlightening beings know form as it really is, know the assemblage of form as it really is, know the extinction of form as it really is, know the path to extinction of form as it really is; they know sensation, perception, conditioning, and consciousness as they really are, know the assemblage of sensation, perception, conditioning, and consciousness as it really is, know the extinction of sensation, perception, conditioning, and consciousness as it really is, and know the path to extinction of sensation, perception, conditioning, and consciousness as it really is. They know ignorance as it really is, know the accumulation of ignorance as it really is, know the extinction of ignorance as it really is, know the path to extinction of ignorance as it really is. They know craving as it really is, they know the accumulation of craving as it really is, they know the extinction of craving as it really is, they know the path to the extinction of craving as it really is. They know Buddhist discipleship as it really is, they know the principles of discipleship as they really are, they know the development of discipleship as it really is, they know the nirvana of Buddhist disciples as it really is. They know individual enlightenment as it really is, they know the principles of individual enlightenment as they really are, they know the development of individual enlightenment as it really is, they know the nirvana of individual illuminates as it really is. They know enlightening beings as they really are, they know the principles of enlightening beings as they really are, they know the development of enlightening beings as it really is, they know the nirvana of enlightening beings as it really is.

ji ltar shes she na/ las dang / las kyi rnam par smin pa dang / bya ba dang / mngon par 'du byed pa dang / gso ba dang / gsog dang / snying po med pa dang / bdag med par rab tu shes te/ chos gang yang snying po can du shes pa med do/ / chos gang la'ang rang bzhin du 'dogs pa med de; ngo bo nyid kyi mthas gtugs par thams cad rab tu shes so/ / sems can rnams la yang de bzhin nyid kyi don du chos ston te/ de ci ston ce na/ 'jig pa med pa'i phyir chos ston te/ gang 'jig pa med pa'i phyir zhe na/ gzugs 'jig pa med pa'i phyir/ tshor ba 'jig pa med pa'i phyir/ 'du shes 'jig pa med pa'i phyir/ 'du byed 'jig pa med pa'i phyir/ rnam par shes pa 'jig pa med pa'i phyir chos ston to/ / ma rig pa 'jig pa med pa'i phyir/ nyan thos kyi chos dang / rang sangs rgyas kyi chos dang / byang chub sems dpa'i chos 'jig pa med pa'i phyir chos ston to/ / de ci'i phyir zhe na/ chos ni/ ma skyes pa/ 'dus ma byas pa/ byed pa po med pa/ rtsod pa med pa/ gnas pa med pa/ ma skyes pa/ mi 'byung ba/ ma blangs pa/ nye bar ma blangs pa/ byed pa med pa ste/

“In what way do they know these things? They know that actions resulting from past deeds, productions of causes and conditions, are all unreal and empty, are not self, are not substantial—there is not a single thing that can be established. Wishing to cause sentient beings to know their true nature, they explain it extensively for them. What do they explain to them? They explain that all things cannot be destroyed What things cannot be destroyed? Material form cannot be destroyed, sensation, perception, conditioning, and consciousness cannot be destroyed; ignorance cannot be destroyed; the principles of discipleship, self-enlightenment, and universal enlightenment cannot be destroyed. Why? Because all things are uncreated, have no creator, have no explanation and no location, are unborn and unoriginated, not given and not taken, have no motion and no function.
de shes rab kyi gter de lta bu dang ldan pas las gron chung ngus chos thams cad la mkhas pa/ gzhan gyi dring mi 'jog pa yang dag pa ji lta ba bzhin du rab tu shes so/ /

“Enlightening beings developing such a measureless treasury of wisdom, understand all things by a minimum of devices, spontaneously comprehending them clearly and not depending on another for enlightenment.

shes rab kyi gter de yang mi zad pa yin te/ de yang shin tu bstan pa bcus mi zad pa yin no/ / bcu gang zhe na/ thos pa la mkhas pas mi zad do/ / dge ba'i bshes gnyen la bsnyen pas mi zad do/ / tshig rab tu dbye ba la mkhas pas mi zad do/ / chos kyi dbyings la 'jug pa mngon par sgrub pas mi zad do/ / rgyan gcig pa'i ye shes kyi rjes su zhugs pas mi zad do/ / bsod nams thams cad shin tu bsags pas mi zad do; ; skyo ba med pa mngon par sgrub pas mi zad do/ / gzungs thams cad kyi sgor zhugs pas mi zad do/ / sems can thams cad kyi skad dang sgra dang brjod pa sna tshogs kyi phyir mi zad do/ / 'gro ba thams cad kyi yid gnyis dang / nem nur dang / the tshom yang dag par gcod pa'i phyir mi zad do/ / sangs rgyas kyi rnam par 'phrul pa thams cad yongs su bstan pas sems can thams cad nye bar 'tsho ba dang / yongs su smin par bya ba dang / gdul ba'i spyod pa shin tu rtogs pa'i phyir mi zad de/ mi zad pa shin tu bstan pa bcu po de dag gis shes rab kyi gter de mi zad pa yin no/ /

“This inexhaustible treasury of wisdom is said to be inexhaustible because it has ten kinds of inexhaustibility: because the skills of learned enlightening beings are inexhaustible; because association with wise people is inexhaustible; because appropriate analysis of expressions and meanings is inexhaustible; because entry into the profound realm of reality is inexhaustible; because adornment with uniform knowledge is inexhaustible; because indefatigably accumulating all virtues is inexhaustible; because entering the gates of all concentration formulae is inexhaustible; because ability to distinguish the sounds of languages of all sentient beings is inexhaustible; because the ability to cut off the doubt and confusion of all sentient beings is inexhaustible; because manifesting all spiritual powers of Buddhas for all sentient beings to teach and civilize them and cause them to practice the teaching without interruption is inexhaustible.
kye rgyal ba'i sras dag / 'di ni/ byang chub sems dpa' rnams kyi shes rab kyi gter yin te/ de la gnas pa'i byang chub sems dpa' rnams shes rab dang / ye shes bla na med pa rnam par 'tshang rgya'o/ /
“This is called the great enlightening beings’ seventh treasury, of wisdom: those who abide in this treasury attain inexhaustible knowledge and wisdom, and are able to enlighten all sentient beings.”

kye rgyal ba'i sras dag / de la byang chub sems dpa' rnams kyi dran pa'i gter gang zhe na; kye rgyal ba'i sras dag/ 'di la byang chub sems dpa' dran pa dang ldan pa yin te/ de yang rgyud rmongs pa med pa'i dran pas sngon gyi gnas rjes su dran te/ 'di ltar tshe gcig kyang rjes su dran no/ / tshe gnyis dang / gsum dang / bzhi dang / lnga dang / tshe brgya dang / stong dang / tshe brgya phrag du ma dang / tshe stong phrag du ma dang / tshe brgya stong phrag du ma dang / 'jig pa'i bskal pa'am/ 'du ba'i bskal pa'am/ 'jig pa dang 'du ba'i bskal pa'am/ 'jig pa'i bskal pa du ma dang / 'du ba'i bskal pa du ma dang / 'du ba dang 'jig pa'i bskal pa du ma dang / bskal pa brgya dang / bskal pa stong dang / bskal pa brgya stong dang / bskal pa bye ba khrag khrig brgya stong dang / bskal pa bye ba khrag khrig brgya stong tshad med pa dang / bskal pa bye ba khrag khrig grangs med pa/ bsam gyis mi khyab pa/ mtshungs pa med pa/ kun tu mtha' yas pa/ mu med pa/ sa mtshams med pa/ gzhal du med pa/ brjod du med pa gnyis dang / gsum dang / bzhi dang / lnga dang / gzhung de bzhin du brjod du med pa yang brjod du med pa dang / sangs rgyas skye bar lung bstan pa shin tu brjod pa gcig dang / gnyis dang / gsum dang / bzhi dang / lnga nas sangs rgyas skye bar lung bstan pa shin tu brjod du med pa brjod du med pa'i yang brjod du med pa dang / sangs rgyas skye ba gcig bstan te/ de dang mtshams sbyar ba'i lung bstan pa gcig dang / gnyis dang / gsum dang / bzhi dang / lnga nas sangs rgyas skye ba shin tu bstan te/ de dang mtshams sbyor ba lung bstan pa brjod du med pa'i yang brjod du med pa dang / mdo'i sde gcig dang / gnyis dang / gsum dang / bzhi dang / lnga nas brjod du med pa'i yang brjod du med pa'i bar dang / dbyangs kyis bsnyad pa'i sde dang / lung bstan pa'i sde dang / tshigs su bcad pa'i sde dang / gleng gzhi'i sde dang / ched du brjod pa'i sde dang / 'di ltar 'das pa'i sde dang / skyes pa rabs kyi sde dang / shin tu rgyas pa'i sde dang / chos rmad du byung ba bstan pa'i sde dang / man ngag bstan pa'i sde gcig dang / gnyis dang / gsum dang / bzhi dang / lnga nas brjod du med pa'i yang brjod du med pa'i bar dang / 'khor 'dus pa gcig dang / chos kyi mtshams sbyar ba gcig nas chos kyi mtshams sbyar ba brjod du med pa'i yang brjod du med pa'i bar dang / dbang po sna tshogs gcig nas dbang po sna tshogs brjod du med pa'i yang brjod du med pa'i bar dang / dbang po rnam pa tha dad pa sna tshogs gcig nas dbang po tha dad pa sna tshogs brjod du med pa'i yang brjod du med pa'i bar dang / nyon mongs pa sna tshogs gcig nas nyon mongs pa sna tshogs brjod du med pa'i yang brjod du med pa'i bar dang / ting nge 'dzin sna tshogs gcig nas ting nge 'dzin sna tshogs brjod du med pa'i yang brjod du med pa'i bar dag kyang dran pa dag pa/ dang ba/ rnyog pa med pa/ rnam par gsal ba/ rdul med pa/ rdul dang bral ba/ dri ma med pa/ 'od gsal ba/ sang sang po/ / bsgribs pa med pas rjes su dran no/ /

“What is great enlightening beings’ inexhaustible treasury of recollection? The enlightening beings cast off ignorance and confusion and attain full mindfulness. They remember one lifetime, two lifetimes, even ten lifetimes, a hundred, a thousand, a hundred thousand, countless hundreds of thousands of lifetimes in the past, their ages of formation, ages of decay, and ages of both formation and decay. And not just one age of formation, not just one age of decay, not just one age of formation and decay—a hundred ages, a thousand ages, a hundred thousand trillion ages, even up to countless, measureless, boundless, incomparable, uncountable, incalculable, unthinkable, immeasurable, inexplicable, unspeakably unspeakable numbers of Buddhas’ names. They remember the appearance in the world and forecasting of one Buddha up to an unspeakably unspeakable number of Buddhas. They remember the emergence in the world and discourses of one up to an unspeakably unspeakable number of Buddhas—as they remember the discourses, so also they remember the recapitulative verses, predictions, poems, stories, extemporaneous expositions, tales of past events, tales of past lives, extensive and universal teachings, miracles, metaphors, and analytic philosophy of the Buddhas. They remember one assembly, up to an unspeakably unspeakable number of assemblies. They remember the exposition of one teaching, up to an unspeakably unspeakable number of teachings. They remember the various natures of one faculty, up the various natures of an unspeakably unspeakable number of faculties. They remember the innumerable various natures of one up to an unspeakably unspeakable number of faculties. They remember the various natures of one affliction, up to the various natures of an unspeakably unspeakable number of afflictions. They remember the various natures of one up to an unspeakably unspeakable number of afflictions. This recollection is of ten kinds: dispassionate, serene recollection; pure, clear recollection; unmuddled recollection; thoroughly lucid recollection; recollection apart from defilement; recollection apart from various defilements; untainted recollection; radiant recollection; pleasant recollection; unhindered recollection.

byang chub sems dpa'i dran pa de ni/ 'jig rten gyi 'khrul pas mi 'phrog pa yin/ phas kyi rgol ba thams cad kyis nye bar nyon mongs par mi nus pa yin/ sngon gyi dge ba'i rtsa ba shin tu sbyangs pa yin/ 'jig rten gyi chos thams cad kyis ma gos pa yin/ bdud dang mu stegs can dmigs pa la gnas pa gzhan gyis mi chod pa yin/ tshe rabs kun tu 'pho ba'i lus shin tu bstan pa thams cad kyis brjod par mi nus pa yin/ sngon gyi mtha' dang / phyi ma'i mtha' dang / da ltar byung ba'i mthas rnam par mi chod pa yin/ 'jig rten gyi khams su skye ba dang gnas pa thams cad kyis skyon du ma gyur pa yin/ sangs rgyas skyes pa'i 'khor gyi dkyil 'khor du 'jug pa shin tu bstan pa thams cad kyis thogs pa med pa yin/ sangs rgyas kyi chos thams cad kyi rjes su song ba yin te/

“When enlightening beings dwell in this recollection, no one from any world can disturb them, no different philosophies or arguments can change or move them. Their roots of goodness from the past are all purified. They are not influenced by or attached to mundane things. Demons and outsiders cannot harm them. They can be reborn in different forms without forgetting anything. Their teaching in past and future is inexhaustible. They live together with sentient beings in all worlds with never any faults or misdeeds. They enter the congregation at the sites of enlightenment of all Buddhas without impediment, and are able to associate with all Buddhas.
kye rgyal ba'i sras dag / 'di ni/ byang chub sems dpa' rnams kyi dran pa'i gter te/ brgyad pa'o/ /
This is called the great enlightening beings’ eighth treasury, of recollection.

kye rgyal ba'i sras dag / de la byang chub sems dpa' rnams kyi rtogs pa'i gter gang zhe na/ kye rgyal ba'i sras dag / 'di la byang chub sems dpa' rtogs pa dang ldan pa yin te/ de yang yi ge de bzhin gzhan ma yin pas mdo'i tshul gyi chos ston to/ / de ni/ tshe'i rgyud gcig pa yang yongs su 'dzin to/ / tshe'i rgyud brjod du med pa'i yang brjod du med pa'i bar du yongs su 'dzin to/ / sangs rgyas kyi mtshan gcig kyang yongs su 'dzin to/ / sangs rgyas kyi mtshan brjod du med pa'i yang brjod du med pa'i bar du yang yongs su 'dzin to/ / bskal pa grangs med pa bstan pa gcig kyang yongs su 'dzin to/ / bskal pa grangs med pa bstan pa brjod du med pa'i yang brjod du med pa'i bar du yang yongs su 'dzin to/ / de bzhin gshegs par lung bstan pa brjod pa gcig kyang yongs su 'dzin to/ / de bzhin gshegs par lung bstan par brjod pa brjod du med pa'i yang brjod du med pa'i bar du yang yongs su 'dzin to/ / mdo gcig kyang yongs su 'dzin to/ / mdo brjod du med pa'i yang brjod du med pa'i bar du yang yongs su 'dzin to/ / 'dus pa gcig kyang yongs su 'dzin to/ / 'dus pa brjod du med pa'i yang brjod du med pa'i bar du yang yongs su 'dzin to/ / chos kyi mtshams sbyar ba gcig kyang yongs su 'dzin to/ / chos kyi mtshams sbyar ba brjod du med pa'i yang brjod du med pa'i bar du yang yongs su 'dzin to/ / dbang po rnam pa tha dad pa sna tshogs gcig kyang yongs su 'dzin to/ / dbang po rnam pa tha dad pa sna tshogs brjod du med pa'i yang brjod du med pa'i bar du yang yongs su 'dzin to/ / nyon mongs pa sna tshogs gcig kyang yongs su 'dzin to/ / nyon mongs pa sna tshogs brjod du med pa'i yang brjod du med pa'i bar du yang yongs su 'dzin to/ / ting nge 'dzin sna tshogs gcig kyang yongs su 'dzin to/ / ting nge 'dzin sna tshogs brjod du med pa'i yang brjod du med pa'i bar du yang yongs su 'dzin to/ / kye rgyal ba'i sras dag / 'di ni/ byang chub sems dpa' sems dpa' chen po rnams kyi rtogs pa'i gter te/ mi zad pa/ kun tu mtha' yas pa/ dgang dka' ba/ gting rnyed par dka' ba/ sgrub par dka' ba/ mi 'phrog pa/ thug pa med pa/ bdag nyid che ba'i sangs rgyas kyi yul gyi rjes su song ba ste/ 'di ni/ gter dgu pa'o/ /

“What is great enlightening beings’ treasury of preservation? The enlightening beings preserve the discourses of the Buddhas, their expressions, meanings, and principles, without forgetting or losing them, for one lifetime, up to an unspeakably unspeakable number of lifetimes. They hold the name of one Buddha up to an unspeakably unspeakable number of Buddhas. They preserve the reckoning of one age up to an unspeakably unspeakable number of ages. They preserve the predictions of one Buddha up to an unspeakably unspeakable number of Buddhas. They preserve one scripture, up to an unspeakably unspeakable number of scriptures. They hold one assembly, up to an unspeakably unspeakable number of assemblies. They preserve the explanation of one doctrine, up to the explanations of an unspeakably unspeakable number of doctrines. They keep in mind the countless various natures of one up to an unspeakably unspeakable number of faculties. They keep in mind the countless various natures of one, up to an unspeakably unspeakable number of afflictions. They keep in mind the countless various natures of one, up to an unspeakably unspeakable number of concentrations. This treasury of preservation is boundless and hard to fill; it is hard to reach its depths, hard to approach. No one can conquer it. It is measureless and boundless, inexhaustible, and has great power. This is in the realm of Buddhas and can only be completely comprehended by a Buddha. This is called the great enlightening beings’ ninth treasury, of preservation.

kye rgyal ba'i sras dag / de la byang chub sems dpa' rnams kyi blo gros kyi gter gang zhe na/ kye rgyal ba'i sras dag / 'di la byang chub sems dpa' yang dag par rtogs par byed pa'i rtogs pa dang ldan zhing blo gros dang ldan pa yin te/ mdo sde thams cad dang mi 'gal bas de chos ston pa'i tshe dngos po yongs su ldog pa gcig kyang brtsams te chos ston pa nas dngos po yongs su ldog pa brjod du med pa'i yang brjod du med pa'i bar du chos ston to/ / sangs rgyas kyi mtshan gcig nas tshul de bzhin du brjod du med pa'i yang brjod du med pa'i bar dang / 'jig rten gyi khams gcig dang / sangs rgyas su / chos snang ba shin tu bstan pa thob pas sems can thams cad la chos ston to/ / chos kyi sgo snang ba'i chos can lce yangs pas 'jig rten gyi khams thams cad du mngon par go bar byed pa dang / dbyangs kyi yan lag la mkhas pas 'gro ba thams cad tshim par byed pa dang / dbang po ji lta ba bzhin du mgu bar byed pa dang / nyon mongs pa dang / kun nas 'khor ba thams cad rnam par bzlog pa dang /

“What is great enlightening beings’ treasury of elocution? The enlightening beings have profound knowledge and wisdom and know reality. They extensively explain all things for sentient beings without contradicting the scriptures of all the Buddhas. They explain one doctrine, up to an unspeakably unspeakable number of doctrines. They explain one Buddha-name, up to an unspeakably unspeakable number of Buddha-names. In this way they explain one world, one Buddha’s predictions, one scripture, one assembly, one teaching, countless various natures of one faculty, countless various natures of one affliction, countless various natures of one concentration, up to an unspeakably unspeakable number of all of these. They may speak for a day, for a fortnight, for a month, for a century, for a millennium, a hundred millennia, an eon, a hundred eons, a thousand eons, a hundred thousand eons, a hundred thousand billion trillion eons, or for countless, innumerable eons, up to unspeakably unspeakable numbers of eons—the number of eons might be exhausted, but the meanings and principles in a single sentence or phrase can hardly be exhausted. Why? Because the enlightening beings have developed these ten inexhaustible treasuries, and can comprehend all things; the method of concentration formulae is obvious to them, containing incalculable millions of concentration spells. Once they have attained mental command of this concentration formula, they can extensively explain things to sentient beings by the light of truth. When they preach, with a universal tongue they produce marvelous sounds which fill all worlds in the ten directions, satisfying all according to their faculties and natures, so that their minds are happy and freed from the entangling taints of all afflictions.

“The intellectual and interpretative powers of the enlightening beings, able to enter into all linguistic expression, spoken and written, causes all sentient beings to continue the lineage of Buddhas. Their purity of mind is continuous, and they expound the truth endlessly by the light of the teaching, without becoming weary. Why? Because these enlightening beings have developed boundless bodies as extensive as space, pervading the cosmos.

kye rgyal pa'i sras dag / 'di ni/ byang chub sems dpa'i gter bcus blo gros mi zad pa/ thug pa med pa/ 'dres pa med pa/ rnam par mi chod pa/ rgyun gcad par mi nus pa; phyir mi ldog pa/ gting rnyed par dka' ba/ ring du gyur pa/ sgo kun dang ldan pa/ sangs rgyas thams cad kyi chos la zhugs pa'o/ /

“This is called the enlightening beings’ tenth treasury, of elocution. This treasury is inexhaustible, unbroken, uninterrupted, unchanging, unhindered, never receding. It is extremely deep, and indeed bottomless. It is hard to enter. It goes into the doors of all the Buddha teachings.

kye rgyal ba'i sras dag / bcu po de dag ni/ byang chub sems dpa' rnams kyi gter te/ mi zad pa'i rnam pa bcus mi zad pa yin no/ / bla na med pa yin no/ / mthar rdzogs pa'i sangs rgyas su 'gyur ba yin no/ / bcu gang zhe na/ sems can thams cad kyi nye bar 'tsho ba dang / sngon gyi smon lam legs par yongs su bsngos pa dang / bskal pa thams cad kyi grangs gcad du med pa dang / nam mkha'i dbyings dang mnyam pa nyid du khong du chud pa'i phyir sems tshad med pa dang / 'dus byas kyis ma gos pa'i phyir 'dus ma byas la yongs su bsngos pa dang / de ma thag pa'i yul du gyur pas chos thams cad zad mi shes pa dang / smon lam chen po tha dad pa med pa dang / spyod pa la gnas pa'i stobs shin tu 'dzin pa dang / sangs rgyas thams cad kyis yongs su bzung ba dang / chos thams cad sgyu ma lta bur 'jug pa mtha' dang dbus med pa la zhugs pa ste/ mi zad pa'i rnam pa bcu po 'di dag gis 'jig rten gyi bya ba thams cad kyi mthar phyin pa zad mi shes pa'i gter chen por 'gyur ro/ /

“These ten inexhaustible treasuries have ten kinds of inexhaustibility which enable enlightening beings to ultimately achieve unexcelled enlightenment. What are they? They benefit all sentient beings; they skillfully dedicate their original vows; they have no end throughout all time; throughout the realm of space all become enlightened, their minds unbounded; their dedication involves striving but they are not attached; the phenomena in the realm of an instant of thought are infinite; the mind of great vows never changes; they skillfully take in all concentration formulae; they are guarded by all the Buddhas; they comprehend all things are like phantoms. These are the ten inexhaustible things which can enable deeds in all worlds to attain the ultimate inexhaustible great treasuries.”
